Sir:

I have the honor to report that it is the wishes of Miss M. Hickey, teacher at South Bay Day School, to keep hens in order to supply herself with eggs and teach the people and pupils how to care for them.

Kindly inform me if the Department is in a position to build a coop of the following dimensions:

Length 12 feet, width 8 feet, height of front 6 feet and back 4½ feet.

She proposes to furnish the fowl.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo in which you inform the Department that a hen coop at the South Bay School will cost $60.

In reply I beg to say that this amount is greater than the Department cares to expend for a hen coop at this place. Possibly you could get the Indians to furnish some logs, and the Department would be willing to allow them not exceeding $15 for the other incidental expenses.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

Authorized by Official Letter No.151721/T of September 4th last, I have the honor to enclose herewith an account in favour of David Shawande amounting to $20.00 for erecting a hen coup at the South Bay Day School.

The coup is built of logs eight feet wide and ten feet long with a good floor and roof, and well plastered.

I let the contract to the Indian for $15.00, but after he started he found that it was impossible to complete it for that amount, so I had to allow him $20.00.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

CANADA
Ottawa, September 24, 1920

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report from Mr. Inspector Bennett who visited the South Bay Indian Day School on the 14th instant.

As this school has been closed for sometime, the Inspector states that considerable equipment is required both for the school and teacher's residence in order to make them habitable.

You will be good enough to purchase the following and have them supplied to the school at an early date: two stove pipe elbows, two brooms, 6 bars of Lifebuoy soap, four yards of towelling, three yards of oil cloth 36 inches wide, one small wash tub, a wash board, one scrubbing brush, a lamp, a coal oil can, a potato set and kettle. When purchasing the above articles you should obtain prices from several dealers and purchase from the party quoting the lowest price.

When forwarding the accounts you should state the names of the parties from whom you obtained prices and also the price quoted by them.

The Inspector also states that some of the window panes are broken. You will be good enough to have these repaired. He also states that the foundation of the building requires some repairs and recommends that another closet be built. You will be good enough to furnish the Department with an estimate of the probable cost of having these repairs attended to at an early date.

If you consider that any other articles are required for the school or the teacher's residence you should request authority from the Department for purchasing the same and furnish an estimate of the probable cost.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6222, file 473-5, part 2)
Sir:

In reply to the fifth paragraph of Official Letter No. IS-5-6 of September 24th last, in regard to the repairs recommended by Mr. Inspector Bennett to the South Bay School, I have the honor to report that I consider that it will cost $25.00 to have the foundation of the school repaired, and Mr. McMartin of this village who is the only contractor here has asked $60.00 to erect a suitable closet at the school.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, October 13, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant in regard to the repairs recommended by Mr. Inspector Bennett to the South Bay School and furnishing an estimate at which they can be completed, also an estimate of the cost of erecting a closet.

In reply I beg to say that you will be good enough to have the repairs to the window panes and the foundation of the building completed, and the cost should not exceed your estimate of $25.00. You should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. The work should be performed at the lowest possible cost and should be attended to as soon as possible, in order that it can be completed before the cold weather sets in.

With reference to the closets I beg to say that it is considered that separate closets should be built, one for the boys and one for the girls, and if Mr. McMartin will undertake the building of two separate closets for the price quoted, namely, $60.00, you may arrange with him to have this work done. A screen should be erected in front of each closet. If the price quoted for the work is satisfactory to Mr. McMartin you should arrange with him to undertake the work and have it completed as soon as possible and you should point out to him the site on which the closets should be erected. They should be some distance from the school and also some distance apart.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

Ottawa, October 14, 1920.

Sir,

In further reference to previous correspondence regarding the repairs required at the South Bay Indian Day School I beg to refer you to your report on this school for the month of September, last, in which you state that the woodshed at this school requires a new door, at a cost of $3.50; also that the flag pole requires a new rope and that there should be about two dozen hooks put in the cloak room, so that the pupils can hang their wraps.

You should arrange to have a new door put on the woodshed and the cost should not exceed your estimate.

You should purchase a new rope for the flag pole and two dozen hooks for the cloak rooms and have the rope put on the flag pole and the hooks put up in the cloak room.

When the above work is completed you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. All this work should be done as cheaply as possible and should receive your immediate attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

Dear sir,

There is at South Bay, Manitoulin Unceded reserve one school house and separately the teacher's residence. As you know this school has been closed since years. The Indians of the place would like to use it for parties, bingo or else to make few pennies for the church but the Indians of South Bay band claim the ownership and object to it though they themselves come to the church, that they like to see nice and clean.

Would you be kind enough to let us know if really this school belongs exclusively to the S.B. band (5 families in all) or if it has been paid also by the Indians of Wikwemikong band. This is what the latter say, that they also paid their share.

If it has been paid by the S.B. band only, would you be kind enough to grant us through Mr. Indian Agent the permission to use it only for that purpose of the church.

The residence of the teacher would be sufficient for that purpose, as the Indians are not numerous.

Thanking you in advance for this great favour.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Rev. Chas. Bélanger, S.J.

Dear Sir,

About two weeks ago I wrote to you or perhaps to the Indian Agent at Manitowaning about the improvements that ought necessarily to be made to the school building at South Bay Manitoulin Island, Ont., in the Agency of Manitowaning.

It is impossible to live in the small lodging of the teacher in the winter, and more yet by the rainy days of the fall. With great difficulty I found an excellent teacher, Miss Pearson, but as soon as she saw the small room that was going to be set together, parlor, kitchen and sleeping room, she would go away immediately. The only reason because the Chiefs agreed to ask your Department for an addition comprising another room and a bed. But the year passed and nothing has been done. Now it has to be done immediately before the bad weather, or the teacher will likely be obliged to move away, being unable to stand any more hardship. I know, dear Sir, what hardship is, having been a missionary for years, and I may tell you that it would be inhuman to let a lady accustomed to comfort in the School of South Bay any longer.

Your Department wants to have good teachers for the Indians schools; but it will be impossible, except if I happen to find one or two of those saints who, for the sake of religion, are ready to sacrifice their life. I may say it in connection with the School of South Bay, of Manitowaning and also to a certain extent of Sagamog. There ought to be warm small
I have provided with the most necessary furniture, and there is nothing else.

Hope, dear Sir, that this state of affairs will receive your immediate attention.

I want a good competent teacher having third class certificate for bushwarming by adding a certain amount to the salary given by the Department. His name is Mr. A. P. O'Malley. But I am afraid that after seeing that there is no pay for him, he may not remain more than a few months. And besides, the supplementary payment that I give him is only for this year, as I may not have the same means next year.

G. A. Arthur

Superior of R.C. Mission.

OTTAWA, 4th August, 1900.

The Secretary:

Father Artus of Wikwemikong calls the attention of the Department to the necessity of furnishing better accommodation for the teacher of the South Bay Indian school and I think that something should be done to fill this want.

Mr Inspector Prendergast in his report on this school states that Miss Moore who is at present in charge, is one of the best teachers he has met in our Indian schools. It would be a pity to lose her services and Father Artus states that she will not remain unless something is done.

The South Bay Indians could afford to pay for an extension to the building and I would suggest that Mr Agent Sims be asked to furnish an estimate of the cost of providing two additional rooms for the teacher's residence.

The want of accommodation is a great drawback in securing a better class of teachers for schools along the North Shore and where the Indians have money I do not see that it could be better expended than in remedying this defect.

Sir,

Referring to official letter dated 7th instant, with reference to the cost of providing two additional rooms for the teacher at South Bay.

Witkumiskong, 19 Febt 1901.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter about the receipt of $300.00 for the erection of the teacher's residence at South Bay, I beg to say that all the materials used was my own property and I sent it for the purpose at the prices indicated. As for the wages given to me, the salary of Mr. Chief Carpenter and of the apprentices is what I charge to the reserve being for workers that are as I may say of my family. Of the men I have here and the rest at South Bay, the Department will not oblige me to run after them and lose a good deal of time.

Besides it appears to me very strange that anyone should be required to undertake this work. It would be a service to the Indians and become no one else would do it. The building made cost more than the $300.00 paid here and besides I will have to pay more than $50 dollars to bring back here our tugboat that was stolen on the last trip.

However if the Department wants it I will have the receipt of the men by and by when I meet them. But being quite what a difference the Department is doing I shall never more do any work on the same conditions.

The work is done, it is worth the money paid for it. I do not think that I charged too much for any of the materials or for the work. This ought to be enough.

Kindly inform the Department.

Your servant in the Lord.

(Signed) G.A. Attees

Sir,

Referring to official letter of date 26th ultimo with reference to an addition to the teacher's quarters at South Bay. I have the honor to report that I have talked with the teacher regarding her proposition and I do not consider it would be at all practical to comply with what she asks for. She asks that the residence be moved and placed behind the school, joining the two buildings with an addition of ten feet. To do this the present wood shed would have to be moved as well as the residence and this work would cost considerable in itself and it is altogether uncalled for.

An addition of the dimensions of 14 X 20 feet with a wood shed 10 X 12 and cellar under the addition complete would cost about $625.00 which would give the teacher and her companion ample room and good accommodation. The above figures are for plastered finish inside, if finished with V joint or V beaded and matched pine it would cost $50.00 more.

To move the old building back of the school and move the wood shed and put on the addition as asked for by the teacher it would cost approximately $750.00 and they would not have anything like as good quarters.

You ask for a sketch showing the present style of the teacher's quarters, in reply to this I beg to say that I do not think a sketch would be of any material use to you; the building is just an ordinary square frame building 16 feet X 20 feet with 12 walls 12 feet high.

The repairs to the school should be attended to without delay, as reported by me last fall the plastering on the inside of the building requires renovating by an entirely new coat of plaster and the outside of the building requires painting. To do these two jobs will cost $143.00 and I would recommend that the necessary authority be given at once so that the work may be finished in the holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Referring to official letter of date 3rd Instant and previous correspondence regarding proposed betterments in the quarters occupied by the teacher and her companion at South Bay.

I have the honor to report that I have gone into this matter quite fully with Mr. McMartin a reliable contractor and the only one available here and the result of same is as follows.

To put up an addition to the present dwelling size 14 X 20 feet with 12 foot walls and a wood shed 10 X 12 with walls 6 feet high, cellar under the addition to the house size 14 X 20 feet would cost $685.00. Limited details as follows.

Dimensions:
Building to be 1½ story 14 X 20 feet X 12 feet high, with wood shed 10 X 12 X 6 feet walls.

Cellar:
To be 14 feet X 20 feet by 6 feet clear of joists and to be under the said addition, walls of good stone and mortar. The walls and floor of same to be cemented with good strong cement or water lime so as to exclude water and the cellar to have adequate drains as well.

Joists:
The Joists to be 2 X 8 inches sound pine, hemlock or spruce set two feet apart.

Walls:
To be 2 X 4 inch scantling doubled at the corners and set at 16 inch centers, all firmly braced and well nailed, roof plates to be of double 2 X 4 inch good sound pine or hemlock, well jointed. See annex re walls.

Roof:
The rafters to be of 2 X 4 inch good sound pine or hemlock, notched at the roof plates and well nailed thereto with tie or collar beam 1 X 6 inches firmly nailed to the rafters, rafters to be set 2½ feet centers, covered with one inch boards and shingle with good cedar clear butt shingles 5 inches to the weather.

You will note that the figures for the addition to the teachers dwelling is a little higher than the figures I gave you in June last. This is owing to the fact that at that time no allowance had been made for cementing the cellar and this is indispensable as were not well cemented it would be full of water every spring owing to the nature of the ground and the location of the building.

Mr McMartin informs me that he would not care to undertake the moving of the old dwelling as suggested by the teacher as on due consideration he says that the building might not stand moving and he would not care to take the chance of a collapse, besides the work has to be performed in a very out of the way place where it is hard to get in appliances for such work as moving buildings and he says that he wishes to withdraw his former offer. I note your remarks as to the authority being given on the 12th Oct. last and that there would appear to be delay or the work would have been undertaken last fall. In answer to this I beg to say that there was not any delay. In order to commence the building it is necessary first of all to pull down an old wood shed that adjoins the teacher's residence. Mr. McMartin consulted with the teacher on the subject and she said that in so far as she was concerned that she would much rather that the shed be left up till spring as should the weather conditions be such as to prevent the completion of the addition last fall the occupants of the dwelling would be very greatly inconvenienced without the old shed.

It was fortunate indeed that he did not commence as the work could not have been completed last fall.

With reference to your criticism in regard to my remarks as to the weather conditions on this island I beg to say that I extremely regret that the Department should have the opinion that I would depart from the truth in reporting any matter entrusted to me. The weather in the month of November was certainly the worst experienced in years. It was winter weather for practically the whole of the month with lots of snow. During December the weather did moderate but at no time during either November or December would it have been safe to start the work and expect to get it finished before the spring. At that season of the year there is no reasonable guarantee that good weather will prevail for any length of time. In so far as the suffering of the teacher is concerned all I can say is that she would have been inconvenienced far more had not common sense been used. I quite agree with you when you say there has been a great deal of trouble in getting this work started and can assure you that your humble servant has done his utmost to get the improvements required for the better accommodation of the teacher. Everything has been done for the best in so far as I am concerned. OTTAWA, Sept. 17th, 1921.

Sir,

The Department has been informed that the school and teacher's quarters at the South Bay Indian Day School are in a poor condition and that the teacher's quarters especially are in need of more furniture, bed clothing and a stove.

I have to request that you will immediately enquire into the conditions at this school and furnish a report as to what is required to make it comfortable for the teacher and children during the coming winter. The living quarters of the teacher should also be supplied with a few articles of furniture, bed clothing and the broken stove should be either repaired or a new stove secured.

You will be good enough to inform the Department as to the various articles required to fit up the teacher's quarters and also give an estimate of the cost of supplying the same. If any minor repairs are required to either the school or the living quarters you should state the requirements and give as full particulars as possible regarding the cost. The Department will expect to hear from by the end of the present month, giving full particulars as asked for in order that any work or articles required can be supplied before the cold weather sets in.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6222, file 473-8, part 1)
Sir,

When I left your office to come to South Bay, it was with the promise from yourself that I should receive any article of furniture, or other household necessity, within reason, tending to my comfort.

Especially does a teacher need a little comfort when he sacrifices a better school & larger salary to come to such a place as South Bay, where he is quite alone, and where his friends are his books, and the nearest white people 14 miles away.

I wonder if you realize what kind of a place this is for a white man, and I also wonder whether you realize in what condition this house & school was, if so now, no wonder a teacher will not stay long in such a house.

But I am not kicking about the school work; I love it, and I am not here for my salary alone, but because I love my work, and believe I should be successful if conditions were made a little more bearable.

The house wants a few things absolutely necessary to show the Indian how the white man lives.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6222, file 473-8, part 1)
The teacher's house should be the centre of the community life here & an example shown in how a person can be clean & neat, but even my windows are bare of blinds or curtains. I should not ask for strips if I had been guilty of breaking them, but they are in the same condition as on Sept 18th last.

The chair broken, & the kitchen table loaned by the chief here, minus a leg. The only other tables which I have are a small writing table which will not even accommodate my register & my writing table where I keep my books & papers, besides a small table very shaky, where I use as a sideboard in the kitchen. Not a scrap of linoleum or carpet on any of the rooms, no door mat, etc., etc. Surely this was a convent, and as such, was O.K., but I am not a Religious & do not intend living an ascetic life.

The stove in school is badly in need of renewal, a Waterman-Waterbury would be the simplest & one which I should understand. There is no ventilation in my school, & I am suffering from headaches continually in school, to say nothing of the conditions of my pupils many of whom are suffering from colds & are prevented from attending. There is no intake for fresh air, two foul air registers.

I am really in love with my work, but if you cannot see your way clear to give me a little comfort in hours and reasonable amount of encouragement to pupils at school, I shall have to resign at the Xmas vacation.
I visited Miss Lavallie's house & school & her house is a palace to mine; why should one teacher have greater comfort than another, especially as Miss Lavallie is not in such an out-of-the-way place as I am.

I have sent in a requisition for just the bare necessities but it has been refused, on what grounds, I know not, presumably because things are being damaged all the time, but I can promise to hand over things just as I found them, or pay for them, if I break them. The damage is done whilst the vaca are on, or when the schools are closed.

Some authority ought to be given to some person to ensure regular attendance of pupils living within the prescribed limits. I have two or three who are kept at home to work, & living only a mile away, & even nearer.

Something ought to be done to prevent the damage of school property by writing filthy language on the girls' lavatory; this is done by the rough element, usually young men, not under my control; these same young men get intoxicated & have been known to violate school property when Miss Lavallie taught here. One has been very offensive to me already, & I expected to thrash those young fellows & will the law back me up if I do so?

Kindly answer at an early date, so that I may be able to decide whether I shall stay on here for a couple of years or resign; believe me, I am in love with my work.

Respectfully submitted,

William W. Lloyd,
Teacher.

September 6, 1949.

Mr. G. Swartman,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

Winisk Indian School

The present missionary teacher, Rev. Father Raymond M. Alain, O.M.I., has forwarded through Mr. Supt. Allan certain forms and reports in connection with his teaching duties.

As this school is situated in your agency it is desired to have your advice on the following points:

(1) What communication with this place is possible during (a) winter (b) summer?

(2) What facilities for teaching exist and how many children can be accommodated therein?

(3) How many children of school age do you estimate would regularly attend school during the winter months?

From the above questions you will gather that it is planned to go ahead with the proposal to operate this school during the winter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Following receipt of your memorandum of the 22nd ultimo, I wrote the two principal tenderers to ascertain if the prices they originally quoted still hold good. Smith and Chapple Limited advise that their tender stands while C. W. Collins Stores state that there will be an advance in prices in mill work.

The tenders were checked, but we found it difficult to compare them, as the tenders secured by the Indian Agent were not uniform. One firm quoted f.o.b. six different points. Our analysis of tenders may be summarized as follows:

(a) Fellow Supply Company, Chapleau, Ontario quote on thirteen items only, one of which is not included in your requisition. There is no advantage in accepting their quotation as their total price is higher than that of their competitors for the same items.

(b) Chas. W. Collins Stores Limited, Chapleau, Ontario quote on the complete bill of material, but adding freight and increased cost of mill work indicated in their letter of the 27th
ultimo, their total cost is approximately equal to that of the third tenderer (Smith and Chapple Limited, Chapleau, Ontario).

To facilitate this action on your part, the three tenders are being returned herewith. Kindly send them back when they have served their purpose.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Mountbatten Indian Day School.

Included in our 1948-49 Estimates is a sum for the construction of a one-room Indian day school and attached teacher's residence on the Mountbatten Indian Reserve, Chapleau Indian Agency.

It is our intention to erect this school using day labour and purchase orders have already been placed by the Departmental Purchasing Agent for the materials required. Originally we made efforts to interest contractors in the erection of this building. At the suggestion of your office, the following contractors were approached concerning the building of the school:

(1) Bignusolo Brothers, Chapleau, Ontario,
(2) Merle Davis, Chapleau, Ontario.

We have been advised by Mr. J. L. Whitney, Clerk in charge, Chapleau Indian Agency, that both these contractors have advised him they are not in a position to undertake this work.

Mr. F. Matters, our Regional Supervisor for Northern Ontario, has recommended that we approach Mr. Larson, who supervised the work at Constance Lake, and attempt to interest him in undertaking the supervision of this school on a day labour basis.

We therefore wrote to Mr. Whitney concerning this proposal and have now received a reply from him, as follows: -
"Replying to your letter as above, the following are the hourly rates paid to Mr. Larson and his crew:

Mr. Larson, Foreman Carpenter $1.40 per hr.
Mr. E. Pink, Carpenter 1.10 " "
Mr. Roy Mitchell, Carpenter 1.10 " "

"I am pleased that you have had a talk with Mr. Matters concerning the construction of this school, as I feel sure if Mr. Larson takes on the construction of this building, it will mean quite a saving to our Branch. His work so far has been first quality, and his ability to overcome obstacles in the isolated points where he has done construction, has been responsible for a very considerable saving in time and money."

I would recommend that you approve the construction of this school on a day labour basis, hiring Mr. Larson and his carpenters at the rates indicated above and using Indian labour for all other requirements.

Acting Director."

Re: Material for Mountbatten Day School.

The firm of Smith & Chapple Ltd., supplying the above noted building material advise that they cannot complete the necessary staircases without further details.

On page 32 of Specifications for standard Combined One Room Indian Day School with Teacher's Quarters the first paragraph under "Staircases" reads as follows:

"Construct the staircases from the basement to the first and second stories in accordance with the working drawings, these specifications and detail drawings to be supplied later, following the best stair building practice."

I understand from the above quotation that there are further specifications and detail drawings available for the construction of these stairs. This being the case would you please forward same to this office and they will be turned over to Smith & Chapple Ltd. so that they may complete the stairs.

Your attention is directed to Superintendent Whitney's letter of March 7th, requesting that he be supplied with a portable cement mixer for use in connection with construction of new homes and a new day school at Mountbatten, Ontario. Please advise if your Division is prepared to assume a portion of the cost if this machine is supplied.

[Signature]

MR. ARMSTRONG,
WELFARE DIVISION.

We are prepared to meet a portion of the cost of the portable cement mixer required in connection with the construction of the new school and new homes at Mountbatten, Ontario. Re: Mountbatten School.

When purchase order #33841 for the above named school was made out in favor of Smith and Chapple Ltd., there were several items contained in the bill of material for standard combined 1 class-room Indian Day school with teacher's quarters attached, which were omitted entirely from the purchase order.

These items are as follows:

1 piece 2"x10"x18'6" which comprises the beam in the basement of the school. This item does not appear to be listed on the specifications list, but is quite necessary in the construction of this building. This beam is shown on basement plan sheet #1/5 of the blueprint.

On page 5 of the specifications, it calls for 1800 square feet, 3/8" thick gypsum board 4"x12" for class-room walls and ceiling. This item is not on the purchase order. Also immediately following this item is one for 4000 square feet 3/8" gypsum board 4"x8"; this item was also omitted. Also missing are 8 double hung sash and frames 10"x12"-4Wx3H as shown on sheets 3/5 and 4/5 of the blueprint for the school. Those are the windows in the cement foundation. In their place on page 3 of the purchase order, under the heading Basement, is an item: 1 casement sash 10"x12"x1 3/8", 12 lights P.G. R.A.B. and D.M. 3Wx4H. The plan does not call for any such window. It would be suitable as one of the basement windows if it had read 4Wx3H but as supplied it is useless.

I might also point out that on sheet #T-1 of the plan for this school, the sketch of the outside toilets calls for 3 removable windows in each toilet and 3 fixed outside screens. Also for 1 6" metal roof jack.
for ventilator for each building. None of these items appear on the purchase order.

When checking this material on its arrival at Tophet, we were, of course, checking against the purchase order and it was not until Mr. Larsen, the carpenter arrived 3 weeks ago, and began checking against the bill of material for this school the above shortages were noticed.

As the basement windows are all missing, we will not be able to proceed with the cement work without knowing the exact size of the hole to be left to accommodate these windows. Another item needed early in the construction will be the large beam for the basement. In view of this I would appreciate hearing from you at your earliest convenience as to what steps can be taken to remedy these shortages.

J.L. Whitney,
Superintendent,
Chapleau Agency.

Extract from Indian Superintendent Whitney's report on his Agency dated July 5th.

On Mountbatten Reserve, the construction of the school is well under way and I expect the apartment will be ready for the teacher by the 1st of September and the school ready for opening by the 1st of October at the latest. It is expected that there will be about 15 children ready to attend the school this fall. These will be mostly children who have been in residential schools because their families were scattered about where no schooling was available.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Mountbatten Day School.

Whilst I was away on Monday last, Mr. Whitney was in the office and left the enclosed requisition and unsigned contract with some notes regarding them.

It appears that Mr. Larsen is not willing to sign any contract. He is prepared to work and have the school ready as quickly as possible but due to the fact that the essential materials are not on the spot he is being slowed up now. He has been employed by us for this last five or six years and during that time has done an excellent job and I have no doubt he will do the same with the school if given a reasonable chance.

I see by a copy of a letter to you dated June 16th that the Chapleau office wrote regarding shortages or errors in material ordered. To date this has not been rectified and a whole month has passed. The plumbing items are covered in the attached requisition.

The letter referred to the Main Beam across the basement; 1,800' and 4,000' Gypsum Board 3/8"; 8 Sash and Frames for basement windows; Removable Windows and Screens for outside toilets; 3, 6" Metal Roof Jacks. The basement windows and beam are needed early in the construction. Further to this list, Mr. Whitney advises Sash Balances are the wrong size. The Purchase order not having specified what size was required.
In view of the delay in this material, I find it difficult to question the wisdom of Mr. Larsen refusing to sign the contract. Actually, it does not call for either bonus or penalty and most people would sign it without any qualms. However, he is the type that will not sign or even promise anything unless he is fairly sure that he can fulfill the promise.

To expedite construction I would suggest that the shortages or errors be traced and supplied as quickly as possible. If at all possible, I will try to get to the school before coming to Ottawa on July 26th.

F. Matters,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Enclosure.

c.c.

Chapleau, Ontario.

Re: Enclosed Voucher No.529 (65)

When ordering the cement mixer for use in this agency and specifically on the Mountbatten Reserve this year, I forgot to order cement wheelbarrows. As the work of construction on the Mountbatten school was urgent, we had to begin pouring cement immediately on receipt of the mixer.

Rather than delay the project, I took it upon myself to purchase three metal wheelbarrows for cement work. These barrows will of course be used with the mixer on all cement projects and without them we would have had a serious delay on the Mountbatten project.

I would request, therefore, that you approve this expenditure and have the enclosed account paid.

Superintendent,
Chapleau Agency.

Re: Mountbatten School

Re: Front Door Locks

In checking the matter of front door locks for the above noted school, I notice on Page 3 of the List of Material that the officer-in-charge will select and purchase exterior lock sets suitable for requirements. Please advise if I am to take this as authority to purchase these locks.

Re: Classroom

The classroom in the above school is nearing completion, but as yet there is no sign of any blackboards having been ordered or shipped for this classroom. These blackboards are not listed on the List of Materials, therefore, I took it for granted that arrangement for their purchase and shipment would be made from Ottawa. Would you please advise what is being done in this matter.

Re: Kitchen Cupboards

These cupboards were supplied by Smith and Chapple Ltd. from Purchase Order No. 33841. Neither the Purchase Order, nor the Bill of Material, nor the Specifications call for any hardware, i.e., hinges, catches and pulls for the doors and drawers and therefore, they were not supplied. Would you please give me your authority to purchase these items locally as the cupboards are installed complete except for these items.
Re: Hardwood Flooring

The Purchases Order did not list nails for the laying of the hardwood flooring for this school. It requires one keg of hardwood flooring nails for laying 13/16" floor. Please advise if it will be in order to purchase these locally.

Re: Outside Toilets

The plans for this school call for two outside toilets, but the list of materials do not show any locks or hinges for same. To be properly completed it will be necessary to purchase two sets of door hinges and latches of same description also seven pairs of strap or T-hinges for cleanout doors and boys' urinals. Please advise if it will be in order to purchase these locally.

Re: Mountbatten Indian Day School

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, the following action may be taken:

(1) Front Door Locks - These may be purchased locally.

(2) Kitchen Cupboards - When Purchase Order 33841 covering the cupboards was issued, it was assumed that they would have hinges, catches and pulls for the doors and drawers. However, if these have not been supplied I presume it will be necessary for you to purchase them.

(3) Floors - You may purchase an extra keg of nails if these are required.

(4) Outside Toilets - The necessary locks and hinges may be purchased.

(5) Classroom - You might let me know the length and width of the blackboard which you consider should be supplied, and an order will be placed immediately with the Government Stationery Office.
When purchasing the locks and other materials authorized in this letter, it is understood that while serviceable articles should be secured, the expenditure should be kept as low as possible.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Att'n - B. F. Neary

Dear Sir:-

Re: Water Pump - Mountbatten Day School
Requisition attached

When this day school was being constructed, Mr. Larson, the foreman, drove a pump point under the large store room in the basement and led a pipe from this up through the concrete floor. Using this source of water, he did a large part of the cement work and he advises me that this source of water is practically inexhaustible, as the point is down below the water line in good water bearing gravel.

As the temperature in this part of the country in the winter often goes to fifty and sixty below, it is very difficult, if not impossible, to maintain an outside pump. In view of this, I would request that you give this requisition your favourable consideration so that this pump can be installed in the basement of the school.

Yours very truly,

J. L. Whitney,
Superintendent,
Chapleau Agency.

Memorandum:

Mr. L. Brown,
Reserves and Trusts Division

Murray Hill Indian Day School.

It is our intention to erect a new Indian day school on the Wikwemikong Reserve in the Manitoulin Island Agency. I recently visited the proposed site of the school and selected an area which would be suitable. It is the north-west corner of a piece of property in the Maisangwi Settlement, owned by Thomas Murray. It is approximately two acres in extent. Could I please be advised as to what action can be taken towards having this property made available for school purposes. I interviewed the owner and he agreed to sell us his property for $50.00.

Bernard F. Heary,
Superintendent of Education.
May 25, 1948.

Mr. C. R. Johnston,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Manitowaning, Ontario.

Murray Hill Indian Day School.

Since my return to Ottawa, the following progress has been made with regard to the erection of the above one-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence:

(a) I have submitted the name of Mr. M. Brown to the Minister's office for the necessary approval in hiring him as a foreman carpenter.

(b) I have also made enquiries with regard to the release of the property previously agreed upon as a site for the school. I will probably be writing to you in the near future with regard to the surrender of this property and its subsequent sale to the Department. As soon as the necessary approval is obtained for the hiring of Mr. Brown, we will submit to the Departmental Purchasing Agent the usual bill of materials for this school.

Bernard F. Heary,
Superintendent of Education.

Ottawa, May 17, 1948.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Murray Hill Indian Day School,
Manitoulin Indian Reserve.

With the establishment of young people on farms on the outskirts of Wikwemikong, it has become apparent that we must provide further educational facilities. Young veterans, established under the V. L. A., are settling in the vicinity of Murray Hill. Mr. Arneil drew the attention of our Education officials to the need for a new school there before he left for British Columbia. The Provincial School Inspector and the local Indian Agent have also requested the establishment of such a school.

Our Superintendent of Education has just returned from an inspection trip to Manitoulin Island and has made a thorough educational survey of the area. A site for the school has been selected and we have been fortunate in obtaining a bid from a local white carpenter who will undertake to supervise the construction of a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence. There are enough Indian carpenters, painters, labourers, etc., available to complete this project under his supervision. It is our intention to have the Departmental Purchasing Agent obtain all the necessary building materials and to have this building erected on a day labour basis. It is therefore recommended that you approve the hiring of Mr. M. K. Brown, R. R. 1, Manitouining, Ontario, as a foreman carpenter at the rate of One Dollar and Thirty cents ($1.30) per hour.

Funds for the erection of this school are provided in our Main 1948-49 Estimates.

Director.

Re: Murray Hill Indian Day School

I acknowledge receipt of telegram dated June 9, with reference to the appointment of M.K. Brown as foreman carpenter for construction of the above school.

Mr Brown has been informed and is ready to begin work immediately; It was my understanding that we could purchase rough lumber and minor incidentals to house tools and supplies. I would also suggest that at least one of the toilets be constructed almost immediately to avoid building a temporary toilet if you will forward the plans for the outside toilets and show the distance and location from the school.

MEMORANDUM: COL. NEARY,
SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION.

Vacation Pay

With reference to your memo. of the 5th instant, enclosing extract from a letter received from Superintendent Johnston, this office so far has had no definite information regarding vacation pay except that such an item has been noticed in detail of last plus contracts similar to that for Workmen's Insurance and Workmen's Compensation. The first I recall, and which was referred to you, was the building of the school at Sarnia by Shaw Construction Company.

It strikes me that this is a matter for administrative decision, and having got into the construction business, is perhaps a matter which you should refer to Mr. Cory with a view to deciding as to whether the Branch is a common employer in the accepted sense. I can, however, tell you of some information I gathered respecting vacation pay in a telephone conversation which I had with the head of our Cost Inspection and Audit Division, and also of a personal opinion in the matter.

First of all, it appears that vacation pay is a matter of labour legislation common to most of the Provinces. In Ontario particularly, where the work being supervised by Mr. Johnston is involved, the matter is under the direction of the Industry and Labour Board, Department of Labour, and the Act is identified as "Act of Work and Vacations with Pay in Industrial Establishments". The method followed is that the employer obtains special stamps from the Province and affixes them to the book of the workman. This book is carried by him from job to job and at the end of the year, due to the fact that he worked 32 weeks, he is entitled to claim vacation pay from the Province, presumably at some local Provincial Employment Office.

It would seem, therefore, that if a White man ordinarily employed at his trade comes to work for the Branch from another employer and is in possession of a book, we have no option but to continue making the contributions on his behalf. On the other hand, the question of recognizing Indian labour as being entitled to vacation pay might be far reaching in its effects on the Branch generally. I take it that the Indians could be considered simply as casual labour on the reserve, and it is only incidental that presently they may be employed in the building of a school, having come from doing such work as building Indian houses (which to a very large extent is welfare or relief matter) or from employment on roads, fencing or digging ditches, for none of which I am sure to date the question of vacation pay has ever been discussed.

If
If, therefore, you do not feel like advising Mr. Johnston that Indian labour should not be considered as entitled to vacation pay, I would suggest that you consult Mr. Cory or write direct to the Provincial Department of Labour for a ruling.

WL/S

Chief Treasury Officer.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Neary,

Re - Ontario Hours of Work and Vacations with Pay Act.

I acknowledge your memorandum of the 8th instant.

Section 91 (24) of the B.M.A. Act reserves to the Parliament of Canada the right to legislate with regard to Indians. It has nevertheless been settled that Indians when off their reserve are subject to such Provincial legislation as is enacted within the scope of the Provincial legislature; nevertheless the question as to whether such general Provincial legislation applies to Indians while on reserves does not appear to have been definitely determined by the courts.

With reference to the Ontario Hours of Work and Vacations with Pay Act, I am of opinion that this Act would apply to Indians when working off reserves and would apply to white men when working on reserves, but that it does not apply to Indians working on reserves. An Indian working on a reserve does not normally engage in industry as a means of obtaining a living. The Act in question, in my opinion, is intended to apply to persons regularly engaged in industry throughout the year and is not intended to apply to Indians engaged as casual labourers in the construction of a small building on an Indian reserve.

I would therefore suggest that you advise the Indian Agent that vacation pay is to be given to whites, but not to Indians employed on this project.

I would further suggest that you advise the Industry and Labour Board, Department of Labour of the Ontario Government of this opinion and suggest that if they do not agree with it that they are free to deal directly with this office in further discussing the matter.

[Signature]

September 11, 1948.

Mr. C.R. Johnston, Supt. of Indian Agency,
Manitowaning, Ontario.

From his recent visit to several schools in your Agency, Mr. Doucet reports the following:

1. Wikwemikong Indian Day School - The school plumbing is leaking between the two floors above the kitchen. The Agent has been authorized to have this checked immediately and the necessary repairs made. The school roof leaks at two places. The Agent has been authorized to have this thoroughly inspected and have the spots where the leakage occurs re-shingled. This may entail a few shingles or a couple of square feet. However, as it is ruining the ceilings and walls, it was necessary to have this done immediately. Ceilings at the spot of leakage will have to be re-plastered. It is not more than a few square feet at each spot.

There is plenty of water in the well but apparently the cylinder of the pump is leaking and would need new leathers. The Agent has been asked to have this done. It should entail very little expense.

The Department confirms the decisions made by Mr. Doucet and wish you to have the above done as soon as possible.

We have received your wire re the condenser and coil for the electrical plant. These articles have been ordered through Fairbanks-Morse and will be forwarded to you as soon as they arrive.

2. West Bay Indian Day School. - A great deal of the cold air enters the kitchen from the foundation. This should be thoroughly banked with the surrounding soil in the Fall and in the Spring cleared away to prevent the lumber from decaying. Prices should be obtained immediately from an insulation company on insulating the school and residence.
A storm porch approximately 5' x 6' should be built at the entrance of the second classroom.

The Department desires you to obtain prices for this insulation at your earliest convenience and also the cost of building the above mentioned porch.

3. Lakeview and Murray Hill - You are authorized to use the rock siding insul brick instead of the red brick for the Lakeview School and if the Company supplying the asbestos shingles for the siding of the Murray Hill School is willing to substitute the rock insul brick, you are hereby authorized to make this substitution.

Obtain a contract for the forced air stoker fed heating plant for the Lakeview two-room school and the gravity system with the automatic draft controls for the Murray Hill one-room Day School. Have these contracts sent to this office at your earliest convenience so that the construction of these buildings may not be held up by the heating installation.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: Murray Hill School

With reference to construction of the above school, I wish to advise up to September 18th, the wage payroll amounts to $7,583.28 leaving a balance of $1,416.72 from the $5,000.00 advanced to pay wages.

This will be sufficient to take care of the next pay period ending October 2nd, but will require a further advance before October 16th.

I would estimate from four to five thousand dollars more will be required to complete the school.

It has occurred to me that since there will not be running water in this school, it would be a great convenience to have a cistern in the basement for soft water.

There is also the matter of a well for drinking water and I find that one acre of land is altogether insufficient to provide a playground.

As the Departmental Surveyor Mr. Baker is now working in the vicinity and as the larger site was rather agreed upon by Mr. Doucet, I am arranging for approximately two acres.

C. H. Johnston,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

Blackboards Murray Hill Indian School.

This will acknowledge receipt of your requisition of ordering feet of blackboard for the above school. Unfortunately, blackboard is in very short supply at present and you can anticipate a delay of several months before this shipment arrives.

We do not wish, however, to hinder work at this school by failing to provide sufficient blackboards. In view of your knowledge of local conditions, you will be able to decide the urgency of providing this item.

Therefore, if necessary, you can take the following action:

(a) Purchase locally pieces of standard untempered masonite, size 'x' (this costs approximately $3.00 each in Ottawa).

(b) Order quarts of blackboard surfacer from your nearest school supply company (as listed below). One quart of this surfacer covers approximately 60 square feet with the necessary three coats. It dries in one day and can be applied by anyone who can use a brush properly. The cost is approximately $2.50 a quart.

(1) Geo. M. Hendry Ltd., Toronto, Ontario.
(2) Moyer School Supplies, Moncton, Montreal, Toronto, Winnipeg, Saskatoon, Edmonton.
(3) Clarke and Stuart Limited, 550 Seymour St., Vancouver.
(4) Christie School Supply, P.O. Box 300, Brandon.

Vouchers covering these accounts can be forwarded here for payment in the usual manner.

When your proper blackboard arrives, this temporary board can be used in the back of the room or elsewhere as required.

Bernard F. Neary,

Re: Murray Hill School

I wish to acknowledge receipt of Department Letters dated March 19th and 24th, File No. 479-5 (E.1) with reference to the above School.

Mr. Charlton has the furnace set up in the school and has done everything possible to have it completed by March 31st but the Company supplying the furnace have held him up for the registers. They have promised however to have them here within a few days and it should then take only about one day to complete the installation.

There is a small amount of work for the Carpenters after the furnace is completed and it is proposed to have Mrs. Agnes Wakegiijig open the school after the Easter vacation.

A set of blackboards came by rail, although I had received no advice from the Department that blackboards were being supplied from an outside source. I had ordered blackboards and trim from L.A. Buck of Little Current early last fall which were delivered only a few days before the other blackboards arrived.

These can probably be utilized in some of the other schools however, and I would suggest they be retained for this purpose as I cannot ask Bucks to take theirs back since they were ordered especially for this school.
Mr. Charlton's account will be forwarded just as soon as the work is completed and it is assumed the remainder of the Carpenter work will be paid by voucher.

Please advise at once whether satisfactory for Mrs. Wakegijig to begin duties after Easter vacation.

Memorandum:

Mr. L. Brown,
Reserves and Trusts.

Lakeview Indian Day School.

It is our intention to erect a new Indian day school on the West Bay Indian Reserve, in the Manitoulin Island Agency. I visited this reserve and selected a site, which should be satisfactory if water can be found. It is approximately two acres in extent and covers the south east corner of the property owned by Andrew Debassige. I can identify this property on a reserve map. Could we please be advised as to what action can be taken to have this property made available for school purposes. I understand that Mr. Debassige is quite prepared to accept our offer of $50.00 for this property.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.
Mr. C. R. Johnston,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Manitowaning, Ontario.

Lakeview Indian Day School.

Since my return to Ottawa, I have taken the following steps with regard to the construction of a two-room Indian Day School with attached teacher's residence on the West Bay Indian Reserve:

(a) I have prepared and submitted a memorandum to Council through our Minister's office, for the necessary authority to enter into a contract with Mr. Wm. J. Ferguson for the construction of this building.

(b) I have made preliminary enquiries with regard to the release of the property upon which we agreed to erect the school.

However, before any definite steps can be taken with regard to the sale of this property, it will be necessary to make sure that an adequate source of water can be obtained. Therefore you are authorized to expend an amount, not in excess of $300.00, in order to have a well drilled as discussed with you recently. It would be appreciated if we could receive reports upon these well drilling activities as they are carried out.

Bernard J. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Lakeview Indian Day School
West Bay Indian Reserve, Manitoulin Agency.

Our former Inspector for Ontario strongly advised the immediate construction of a two-room Indian day school with teachers' residence at the above point. The Provincial School Inspector and the Indian Superintendent drew to our attention the urgent need for the construction of a school in this vicinity. So pressing was the need for educational facilities that an old Indian house was rented and we now have thirty-four children attending school in this Indian house. There are about another thirty children who are being sent to the Spanish Residential School because of the lack of day school facilities.

Our Superintendent of Education visited this reserve and with Mr. Indian Superintendent Johnston inspected the work being done by Mr. William J. Ferguson on the R.C.M.P. quarters at Manitowaning. It is felt that he has made a good job of this contract and that he would be entirely satisfactory for the handling of the school contract. The attached tender was obtained from him.

I enclose Memorandum to Council for the granting of a contract to Mr. Ferguson, as outlined in his attached tender.

With reference to the erection of a new two-room school at West Bay, it was decided on Mr. Neary's recent visit to this Agency to sink a well on the proposed site as early as possible to assure a supply of water.

Arrangements have been made with the only available well driller on the Island to proceed to the site this week.

The cost is higher than expected as the driller claims he must charge $5.00 per foot for drilling and $2.30 per foot for seamless steel casing, the only kind obtainable at present.

It is hoped we do not have to drill a great distance to the rock which will lessen the cost for casing, however, the driller is making this his first job of the season and we have no alternative.

Lakeview Indian Day School

As previously advised you by telegram, an Order-in-Council has been passed authorizing the awarding of the contract for the construction of our standard two-room Indian Day School with attached teacher's quarters to Mr. Wm. J. Ferguson, of Mindemoya, Ontario.

Please find attached three copies of a contract which Mr. Ferguson should sign and return here. We will then have this contract signed by the Deputy Minister and one copy will be sent to Mr. Ferguson for his retention.

The Department authorizes the following changes in specification from standard -

(a) The use of a steel septic tank in place of a concrete tank.

(b) The use of insul brick siding in place of asbestos shingles or cedar siding.

I have recently had an opportunity of inspecting both Asbestos Shingles and Insul Brick Siding at two day schools on the Six Nations Reserve. Our Superintendent there advises me that the Insul Brick is definitely superior, and that he prefers it on many counts to the Asbestos Shingles. It is important, when this insul brick siding is placed near doors at the front of the building, that it be overlapped by covering boards so that
the children are not tempted to tear it off.

We have asked for a stock of blue-prints for this building and will send two additional sets to you for Mr. Ferguson. We are also ordering the cement for the building and will send the plumbing and electricity plans and specifications.

Under separate cover, we will forward the prevailing rates of wages from the Department of Labour.

Superintendent of Education.

6. EXPOSED DRAINS

All soil and drain pipe above the basement floor shall be medium weight cast iron with bell and spigot ends, and shall be clean and free from rust and shall be thoroughly oiled inside and out.

9. JOINTS

All joints in cast iron pipe shall be made with calum and molten lead and thoroughly caulked.

All joints in waste or vent piping shall be made with long sweep recessed cast iron drain fittings.

Where screwed joints are used for soil or waste pipe, they shall have a smooth continuous interior surface.

Joints to fixtures shall be made with proper gaskets and ferrules as required.

Water closets shall be connected to soil drains by means of brass or cast iron floor flange not less than 3/16 inch thick with caulked joints to cast iron soil drain and with approved packing ring.

10. GRADING OF PIPES

Waste and soil piping shall be graded in the direction of flow with a pitch of not less than 1/4 inch to the foot unless otherwise noted on plan or specified.

All horizontal branches of vent piping shall be graded with the same pitch as above toward the fixtures.

All horizontal branches of hot and cold water piping shall be so graded that they may be completely drained through drip connections installed at necessary points.

11. CLEANOUTS

Provide and set fittings in all drain and soil pipes for cleanouts at all points where obstruction might occur and at the ends of all horizontal pipes and all points required by-laws, or as directed or shown on drawings. Also install Barrett cleanouts at foot of all stacks.

Cleanouts shall be full size for pipes up to 4" diameter and not less than 4" for larger pipes. In horizontal runs they shall be closed gas-tight with heavy brass ferrules caulked in and capped with screw cap, and where on drains underground shall finish flush with floor.
12. WATER PIPING

Cold water piping included in this contract shall begin at a point 3'-0" outside of the building, or otherwise as noted on plans.

All domestic hot and cold water piping in this building shall be galvanized steel standard weight, put together with galvanized screwed malleable iron fittings. No water piping shall be laid in any floor slab. Water service pipes within the basement shall be covered as hereafter described, and exposed to view on external walls and below ceilings.

13. HANGERS

Standing runs of cast iron pipe shall be securely fixed in position by means of strong iron supports placed immediately below the hubs.

Horizontal runs of cast iron pipe shall be supported by means of hand iron hanger rings and 3/8 in ch rod supports from the ceiling.

Vertical runs of water pipe shall be supported by means of iron supports same as for cast iron pipes.

Horizontal runs of water piping shall be supported at 8'-0" intervals with rod and ring hangers. No grabbler bar hangers allowed.

14. VALVES

Valves generally shall be gate valves unless otherwise mentioned 2" and under shall be all brass. Over 2" shall be iron body valves with bronze trimmings.

15. FLASHING

Where vent stacks project through the roof they shall be suitably cap flashed with 5 lb. lead to make a satisfactory and watertight job.

16. TESTING

Water Pipings: Contractor will test all water piping before covering, using cold water at 100 lb. pressure.

Drains and vent system shall be tested for leakage by being filled with water to roof level.

Underfloor drains shall be tested for grade using a standard billiard ball.

On completion of the work the sanitary system shall be submitted to a smoke test.

17. SLEEVES AND ESCUTCHEONS

Where exposed pipes pass through floors, partitions or ceilings in finished rooms, they shall be provided with galvanized iron sleeves 1/2 inch larger than the pipe and cast iron or chrome plated pressed steel escutcheons either of the one piece or split ring type.

GENERAL ELECTRICAL SPECIFICATIONS.

1. All clauses of the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

2. Scope of Work

   The Contractor shall supply all materials required and shall install, in a thorough and workmanlike manner, a system of electric wiring as shown on accompanying electrical plan.

   Provide all conduit, wire, cable, fittings, panels, switches, lighting fixtures, wiring devices and all appurtenances necessary for a complete and approved system ready for operation.

3. Rules and Regulations

   All work shall be carried out in accordance with the rules and regulations as set forth in the Canadian Electrical Code together with such additional regulations of the local Inspection Authorities as may be applicable. Before final payment on contract is authorized a certificate of inspection and approval of work from the Inspection Department of the local authorities shall be submitted to the Chief Engineer. The Contractor shall file all necessary plans with the local authorities and pay all fees and take out all permits in connection therewith.

4. Visit the Site

   The Contractor must visit the site and see the conditions under which the work is to be done and all electrical work shall be planned and done in close cooperation with the workmen performing work of the other trades.
5. Materials and Workmanship

All materials and workmanship shall be the best of their respective kinds. All pipes and fittings shall be galvanized. Lighting panels shall be galvanized and finished in black baked-on enamel. Materials shall be new and as detailed on plan and/or as herein specified. Substitutions will be permitted only by written approval of the Chief Engineer. Studs and joists must not be notched or otherwise cut except by drilled holes centred in wood members.

6. Wiring

Except as noted on plan and/or as herein specified the wiring shall be done in 600 volt maximum rubber insulated braid covered wire enclosed in rigid galvanized conduit concealed in ceiling, wall and floor construction. Wiring shown in basement floor slab shall be lead covered cable enclosed in rigid galvanized steel conduit of size noted on plan. Feeder from service switch to lighting panel shall be run exposed.

All wiring shall be done according to Canadian Electrical Code regulations governing this type of installation.

7. Painting and Labelling

All exposed piping and fittings shall be painted two coats approved first quality paint. Inside of panels shall be touched up after installation to remove marks. Panels shall be fitted with combination lock and catch and shall be provided with index cards indicating circuit service.
Electric Fixtures and Lamps.

Supply and install as specified on plan an electric luminaire on each lighting outlet complete with lamps of specified wattage. All incandescent lamps shall be inside frosted 1000 hour 115 volt Mazda quality and fluorescent lamps shall be 40 watt 2500 hour life, white (3200 K), Mazda quality.

9. Cutting.

All cutting of finishing woodwork and ceiling and wall finishes for the installation of lighting fixture outlets and other wiring devices shall be carried out by workmen skilled in this work.

10. Guarantee.

The Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period at his own expense as soon as practicable after being notified in writing that such defect exists.

"Minister" shall mean the Minister of Mines and Resources of Canada, and his successor for the time being in office and includes the Deputy Minister or any acting Deputy Minister, and any duly authorized representative of the Department of Mines and Resources.

Section 2. SUBJECT MATTER

The Contractor covenants and agrees:

(a) To erect, on the West Bay Indian Reserve, on a site selected by the Superintendent, Indian Agency, Manitoulin Island, a two classroom Indian Day School with teacher's quarters according to plans and specifications No. 649 issued by the Lands and Development Services Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources.

(b) To provide all labour, materials, plant and equipment (except such materials as are included in the Government issue, if any) required for the proper completion of the work, and to perform all the work of and incidental thereto;

(c) To provide an efficient administration for and to superintend efficiently the work at all times;

(d) To perform and observe all covenants, terms, provisions and conditions contained in the contract on the part of the Contractor to be performed and observed;

(e) To carry out and perform the work with all possible despatch and to complete the work to the satisfaction of the Minister.

Section 3. PRICE - COST PLUS PERCENTAGE

His Majesty covenants and agrees:

(a) To pay to the Contractor the cost of the work, as defined in Schedule 'A' attached hereto which cost as so defined is hereinafter referred to as "the cost of the work".

(b) To pay to the Contractor a fee equal to

(i) 10% of the net cost of all materials and labour as defined in Schedule "A" (attached), up to any total cost not in excess of $30,000.00

(ii) For any amount by which the total mentioned in (b) i. above exceeds $30,000.00, the net cost of the work only, as defined in the said Schedule "A", or as covered by any extra work order issued by the Department.
(c) It is understood that the "cost of the work" and the Contractor's fee will not exceed.

(d) The said fee referred to in subsections (b) and (c) hereof shall be deemed to cover the entire profit of the Contractor and the necessary services of all executive officers of the Contractor and also all overhead expenses of the Contractor at its general offices or any regularly established branch office, including but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the services of the purchasing, accounting, ordering and contract departments at such general offices or regularly established branch office.

SECTION 4.

REFUNDS AND TRADE DISCOUNTS

The Contractor covenants and agrees to take advantage of any and all refunds and trade discounts and such refunds and trade discounts and any profits (save and except the fee payable to the Contractor as provided in Section 3 hereof) which may be received by the Contractor in any way in connection with the work shall be credited by the Contractor to His Majesty. It is understood and agreed, however, that the Contractor shall notify His Majesty immediately upon placing each order for material to be used in connection with the work upon which a cash discount will accrue, for the purpose of enabling His Majesty to take advantage of such cash discounts if His Majesty deems it advisable, by advancing funds to the Contractor to cover such above-mentioned orders or by paying for such orders out of funds set aside by His Majesty for that purpose, and upon His Majesty advancing such funds to the Contractor to cover such above-mentioned orders, the Contractor shall apply them so that the cash discounts thereon will be realized. Notwithstanding that His Majesty may fail to provide funds to the Contractor to cover such orders or fails to pay for same as provided for above, the Contractor shall be entitled to the benefit of all cash discounts in respect of purchases made by it with its own funds of materials required for the carrying out of this contract. It is understood that His Majesty may supply the Contractor with materials or may make available to the Contractor funds with which to purchase materials required for the purposes of this contract and any and all materials or funds so supplied or made available shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of this contract.

SECTION 5.

LISTS OF MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT SUPPLIERS.

The Contractor shall, before placing any orders for any equipment or materials required for the performance of this contract submit to the Minister a list of the suppliers from which, and the prices at which it proposes to purchase such materials or equipment, and the Contractor shall, if so directed by the Minister, purchase any or all of such materials or equipment from the same or from some other supplier or suppliers designated by the Minister, with which the Department of Mines and Resources may have made special arrangements for the supply thereof with respect to priorities in the delivery thereof.
Section 6.

PAYMENTS.

(a) As promptly as possible after the last day of each month during the prosecution of the work, the Contractor shall furnish to the Minister a certified statement or progress claim of the cost of the work executed in accordance with the rules laid down for the preceding period, such statement to be accompanied by two copies of all payrolls, vouchers and invoices and such other information as the Minister may require and thereupon, if such statement is satisfactory to the Minister, the Contractor will be paid the amount which may be due within fifteen (15) days after such statement or progress claim has been received by the Minister;

(b) Payments shall be made only on the production and delivery by the Contractor to the Minister of a certificate in writing signed by the Indian Agent and, if required by the Minister, by a cost accountant appointed or approved by the Minister, certifying the amount to which the contractor is entitled as aforesaid;

(c) The Contractor shall, when making his final requisition for payment furnish to the Indian Agent satisfactory evidence, supported by a statutory declaration in form approved by the Minister establishing payment by the Contractor of the items listed in all preceding requisitions and such other information as the Minister may require;

(d) The final payment shall not become due until the Indian Agent and, if required by the Minister, a cost accountant appointed or approved by the Minister, shall have issued a certificate that such payment is due and the Contractor shall have produced proof satisfactory to the Minister that no lien does or can exist against the work; in respect to materials, equipment or payment of wages;

(e) Five copies of all progress claims and summaries of invoices in connection with the work shall be rendered by the Contractor to the Indian Agent.
