INTERPRETATION.

Unless the context otherwise requires,

(a) The term "the agreement" means the particular agreement or contract of which in each specific case, these general conditions are expressed to form a part;

(b) The terms "this contract" and "the contract" mean and include the agreement, these general conditions, the specifications and/or labour conditions referred to in the agreement or in these general conditions and all other schedules, exhibits or other documents (if any) annexed to the agreement or referred to therein as being part thereof. In the event of any inconsistencies the provisions of the agreement or of these general conditions shall prevail over the specifications and similarly the provisions of the agreement shall prevail over these general conditions.

(c) The words "herein" and "hereby", "hereof", "hereunder" and similar expressions refer to the contract as a whole and not to any particular subdivision or part thereof;

(d) "Specifications" means any and all specifications, plans and/or drawings at any time furnished for the carrying out of this contract, including the specifications, plans and/or drawings (if any) referred to in the agreement.

(e) "Minister" means the Minister of Mines and Resources of Canada and his successor for the time being in office and includes the Deputy Minister and any Acting Deputy Minister and any duly authorized representative of the Department of Mines and Resources.

(f) "Engineer" shall mean the person designated in the agreement.

(g) "Work" means the work done or required to be done by the Contractor, and when the context permits, includes labour and materials shown or described in the specifications;

(h) The term "sub-contractor" includes a person, firm or corporation having a contract with the Contractor (other than contracts of hire for personal services) for the execution of a part or parts of the work and also a person, firm or corporation furnishing material to the Contractor in connection with the work;

(i) "Government Issue" means all materials, machinery, tools and/or equipment (if any) which may be supplied by His Majesty to the Contractor for the purposes of the work and includes also any specifications supplied to the Contractor for the said purposes, provided however, that the Contractor shall not be entitled to be supplied with any Government issue except as and to the extent (if any) specifically provided in the agreement;

(j) "other contractor" means any person, firm or corporation employed by, or having a contract directly or indirectly with, the Minister otherwise than through the Contractor;
(k) "Allied firm" means any firm, company, or corporation which directly or indirectly controls or is controlled by or is affiliated with the Contractor, and includes any individual or individuals directly or indirectly controlling the Contractor or any such company or corporation as aforesaid;

(l) Any and all rights, powers, authorities and discretions herein, expressed to be conferred upon or vested in His Majesty may be exercised by the Minister (as defined herein) and/or any other person or persons duly authorized in that behalf;

(m) The singular number, where used herein, shall include the plural and vice versa and reference to persons shall include corporations and vice versa.

2. SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNS.

This contract shall endure to the benefit of all and shall be binding upon the heirs, executors, administrators or successors and assigns (subject as hereinafter provided) of the Contractor and the successors of His Majesty; provided that the Contractor shall not be entitled to assign or sublet this contract or any of the work except as herein expressly provided.

3. QUALITY OF WORK.

The work shall be performed by the Contractor using the best materials and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, and in strict conformity with the contract, and to the complete satisfaction of the Indian Agent and the Minister, and at such places as the Indian Agent shall, from time to time, direct.

TIME.

Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

4. CHANGES IN THE WORK.

The Minister may, through the Indian Agent from time to time, by written instruction or drawings issued to the Contractor, make changes in the work, issue additional instructions, require additional work or direct the omission of work previously ordered, and the provisions of the contract shall apply to all such changes, modifications and additions with the same effect as if they were embodied in the contract plans, drawings and specifications.

Instructions shall be deemed to have been duly given to the Contractor if given to the Superintendent or to a foreman of the Contractor's own work, or if given to the Contractor personally or, if the Contractor is a firm or corporation, to a member of such firm or officer of such corporation.

If there is any change in the work, the Minister shall decide if there has been such a material increase or decrease in the scope of the work so that an adjustment should be made in the Contractor's fee and the Minister's decision on the adjustment to be made shall be final.
6. INDIAN AGENT SOLE JUDGE OF WORK AND MATERIALS.

The Indian Agent shall be the sole judge of the work and material, in respect of both quality and quantity, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard thereto, or as to the meaning or intention of the contract and as to the meaning or interpretation of the plans, drawings and specifications shall be final, and no work under this contract shall be deemed to have been done by materials or things provided, so as to entitle the Contractor to payment therefor unless and until the Indian Agent is satisfied therewith, as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the contractor to be paid therefor; provided that any such decision may be altered or cancelled by the Minister.

7. WORK SUBJECT TO CONTROL OF INDIAN AGENT.

The work shall, in every particular, be under and subject to the control and supervision of the Indian Agent.

8. FOREMAN OF WORKS.

A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during working hours, to receive the orders of the Indian Agent. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor and shall carry out all requisitions and instructions of the Indian Agent.

9. DEFECTIVE WORK OR MATERIAL.

Should the Contractor use or employ or intend to use or employ, any material, plant, tools equipment, articles or things, which, in the opinion of the Indian agent, are not in accordance with the provisions of the contract or are in any way unsuitable for the work, or any part thereof, or should the Indian Agent consider that any work is for any reason, improperly, defectively, or insufficiently executed or performed, the Indian Agent may order the Contractor to remove, repair, re-execute or re-perform such defective tools, equipment, articles and things or to properly re-execute and perform such work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall immediately comply with such orders and if the Contractor fails to comply with such orders within twenty-four hours the Indian Agent may, at any time thereafter, execute or cause to be executed the orders so given.

10. CONSUMABLE TOOLS, MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES.

All usable tools (other than tools customarily provided by tradesmen) and all consumable materials and supplies left over after the completion of the work shall, if the Minister so desires, be taken over and be paid for by the Contractor at a fair and reasonable price to be determined by the Minister.

11. WORK NOT COMPRISED IN CONTRACT.

His Majesty may, at any time, without payment therefor, send and employ on, in and about the work other contractors, and workmen, with such horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Indian Agent may deem necessary to do any work not comprised in the contract, and the Contractor shall afford them all reasonable facilities, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for doing such work, the work of the Contractor being interfered with as little as the Indian Agent may deem practicable.
The taking of possession of the whole or any part of the work of the Contractor for such purpose shall not be deemed in acceptance by or on behalf of His Majesty of the whole or any portion of the work comprised in this contract.

12. POWER TO TAKE WORK FROM CONTRACTOR.

In case the Contractor shall make default or delay in commencing, or in diligently executing any of the work or portions thereof to be performed, or that may be ordered under the contract, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, the Indian Agent may give a general notice to the Contractor requiring him to put an end to such default or delay, and should such default or delay continue for six days after such notice shall have been given by the Indian Agent to the Contractor, or should the Contractor make default in completion of the work or any portion thereof within the time limited with respect thereto in or under this contract, or should the Contractor become insolvent or abandon the work or make an assignment of this contract without the consent required or otherwise fail to observe and perform any of the provisions of the contract, then and in every such case, the Minister, for and on behalf of His Majesty, and without any further authorization, may take all the work out of the Contractor's hands and may employ such means as he may see fit to complete the work, and in such cases the Contractor shall have no claim for any further payment on account of the fee stipulated to be payable to the Contractor or in respect of any period, but shall be chargeable therewith, and shall remain liable for all loss or damage which may be suffered by His Majesty by reason of such default, or delay, or the non-completion by the Contractor of the work, and all hopes, machinery, tools, plant and equipment, and all rights proprietary or otherwise, licences, powers and privileges, whether relating to or affecting real estate or personal property, acquired, possessed or provided by the Contractor for the purposes of the work, or by the Indian Agent under the provision of the contract may be used, exercised and enjoyed by His Majesty, for the purpose of carrying out the work as fully to all intents and purposes as they might theretofore have been used, exercised and enjoyed by the Contractor.

13. INSURANCE.

(a) The Contractor, unless otherwise instructed by the Minister shall insure all materials, equipment and the Contractor's plant during the life and at the times during the construction and until the final occupation of the work and shall keep the same and all buildings and structure being constructed and/or erected insured against loss by fire, in such insurance company or companies and in such amount or amounts as may be approved of by the Indian Agent and the policies of such insurance shall be made payable as the interests of the Contractor and His Majesty, may, respectively, appear, and the original policies or certificates of such insurance shall be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch; provided that such buildings or structures need not be insured by the Contractor from and after the date of the occupation thereof by His Majesty.

(b) The Contractor shall maintain such insurance as will protect him from claims under the Workmen's Compensation Acts and from any other claims for damages for personal injury, including death, which may arise from his operations under the Contract. Certificates of such insurance shall be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch.
and shall be subject to their approval as to adequacy of protection; and the Contractor shall indemnify and save harmless His Majesty from and against all claims and demands, loss, costs, damages, actions suits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, occasioned by, or attributable to any such death, or injury, or any damage to, or infringement of, any property or right.

14. GOVERNMENT ISSUE

(a) All items comprised in any Government issue supplied to the Contractor for the purposes of the contract shall always be and remain the property of His Majesty and shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of the contract and the Contractor shall account fully to the Minister for such Government issue in such manner as the Minister may require.

(b) The Contractor shall be responsible for and shall indemnify His Majesty for all loss or damage of or to any and all such Government issue while on the premises of or in the care or subject to the control of the Contractor and shall at its own expense replace, repair or restore to the complete satisfaction of the Minister all such Government issue which may be so lost or damaged; provided that the Contractor shall not be obligated to make good damage caused by reasonable wear and tear or due to causes beyond his control.

15. PRECAUTIONS AGAINST FIRE

The Contractor shall take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the work, and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires, and with all regulations and instructions made and given from time to time during construction, by the Indian Agent with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires.

16. ASSIGNMENTS

The Contractor shall not assign or sublet the contract without the written consent of the Minister first obtained; provided however that (unless specifically the Minister objects thereto and subject also as herein provided) the Contractor may sublet such portions of the work herein contracted for as is customary and usual in the construction of such work, but His Majesty shall not in any way be held liable for the payment of any moneys due to any such sub-contractor, and the Contractor shall be held responsible for the proper performance of every portion of the work herein contracted for.

17. SUB-CONTRACTORS

The Contractor shall, before entering into any sub-contracts for work or materials, notify the Indian Agent in writing of the names of all such proposed sub-contractors and the terms and conditions of such sub-contracts and shall not enter into any such sub-contracts without obtaining the approval of the Indian Agent thereto.

The Indian Agent may, on request, furnish to any sub-contractor wherever practicable, evidence of the amounts certified to on his account.

The Contractor agrees to bind every sub-contractor by the terms of the General Conditions, Drawings and Specifications, as far as applicable to his work.
18. MEMBER OF H. OF C. NOT TO BENEFIT

No member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of the contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.

19. ACCOUNTS

The Contractor shall keep proper accounts and records in such form and detail as shall be satisfactory to the Minister of the day to whom the contract of the work and the invoices, receipts and vouchers relating thereto, and such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers shall at all times be open to audit and inspection by the Minister or his authorized representatives (who may make copies thereof and take extracts therefrom) and the Contractor shall afford all proper facilities for such audits and inspections and shall furnish the Minister and his authorized representatives with all such information as he or they may from time to time require with reference to such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers. If any part of the work is performed by an allied firm (as defined herein) the Contractor shall also cause such allied firm to keep similar accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers with respect to the cost of the work performed by such allied firm and to permit the same to be inspected and audited by the authorized representatives of the Minister. The Contractor shall cause all such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers as aforesaid to be preserved and kept available for audit and inspection at any time and from time to time until the expiration of five (5) years from the date of the termination of the work.

20. WORK TO BE FREE FROM ALL ENCUMBRANCES

Before making any payment on any progress or final estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to furnish evidence that all work performed, and material supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and save His Majesty from and against any and all kinds of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

(a) His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent or industrial design rights or of any alleged patent or industrial design rights (hereinafter referred to as "patent rights") in carrying out his contract, and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights (including any amounts properly payable by the Contractor to any of its sub-contractors pursuant to any similar covenant of indemnity given by the Contractor to any sub-contractor), in respect of anything the model, plan or design of which shall have been provided by or on behalf of His Majesty, but this indemnity shall apply to this contract only.

(b) Save and except as set forth in sub-section (a) of this section, the Contractor shall indemnify His Majesty against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent rights and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights in carrying out this contract.
(c) Before making any payments with respect to any patent rights, the Contractor shall supply to the Minister a statement showing all payments and claims for payment by way of royalties or otherwise which the Contractor or any of its subcontractors will be entitled to make or propose to make to the owner or holder of any patent rights in connection with this contract, and the basis thereof and the parties to whom the same are payable, and shall from time to time promptly advise the Minister of any and all claims or arrangements made or proposed, which would or might result in further or different payments being made by the Contractor or any of its subcontractors by way of royalties or otherwise as aforesaid.

(d) If and when the Minister shall so direct, the Contractor shall make no payment by way of royalty or otherwise with respect to any patent rights referred to in any statement furnished by the Contractor as provided in sub-section (c) of this section, except with the consent of the Minister and subject to such conditions as the Minister may impose and from and after the giving of any such direction by the Minister, His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against any action, claim or proceedings for infringement of the patent rights covered by such direction or for non-payment of royalties or other payments in respect thereof.

22. SANITATION

The Contractor shall comply with, and the work shall be carried on subject to all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said work, and all orders given by the Indian Agent with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the work. The Contractor shall make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

23. INDIAN AGENT'S MARKS

The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, permits to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, buoys and other marks placed on or about the said work by the Indian Agent or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

24. NOTICES

Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under any of the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally, or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman addressed to the address mentioned in the contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence.

25. PROGRESS MEASUREMENTS AND CERTIFICATES NOT BINDING

The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Indian Agent or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Indian Agent in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
26. PROTECTION OF WORK

The Contract and all information issued in connection therewith are confidential and their use must be strictly confined to the work and to the purpose of the contract; and particulars contained therein; and other matter issued in connection therewith, must not be disclosed to unauthorized persons.

The Contractor shall at all times take and cause to be taken all reasonable measures, for the protection of the work against espionage and sabotage, and on the order of the Minister shall dispense with the services of any person employed in, about or upon the work or cause the same to be dispensed with. The Minister shall have full power to send such agency as he may see fit be entitled to maintain on or about the premises where the work or any part thereof is being carried on such police or other protective force as in the opinion of the Minister may be advisable.

27. CANADIAN WORK AND MATERIALS

To the full extent that the same are procurable, only Canadian labour, parts and materials (unless otherwise agreed by the Minister) shall be used in connection with the work.

27a. EMPLOYMENT OF EX-SERVICE MEN

In engaging labour for the work contemplated by this contract, either from the National Employment Service or from Trade Unions with which the contractor has collective agreements, the contractor shall specify that preference shall be given to competent and available ex-service men.

The contractor shall maintain and keep available for inspection by the Minister a record of the names and addresses of ex-service men employed, together with a record of the steps taken to implement this requirement.

28. SALARIES

The salaries payable to engineers, superintendents, draftsmen and foremen shall only be such as shall be approved by the Minister.

29. TERMINATION

(a) Notwithstanding anything in this contract contained the Minister may, by giving notice to the Contractor, terminate the contract (save and except the provisions of this section and of Section 15 of these General Conditions) as regards all or any part or parts of the work or works not thereafter completed. Upon such notice being given, the Contractor shall cease work (including the procuring of materials for the fulfilment of the contract) in accordance with and to the extent specified in such notice but shall proceed with all reasonable speed to complete such part or parts (if any) of the work or works as are by the terms of such notice to be completed and shall also proceed with all reasonable speed to complete up to such time and/or stage as may be specified in the notice any part or parts of the work or works as required by such notice. The Minister may, at any time, or from time to time give one or more additional notices with respect to any or all parts of the work which remain to be completed after the giving of any previous notice or notices.

The contractor would like to use some power tools in construction of the above-mentioned school and has requested to have contracts completed with the H.E.P.C., so that a temporary meter can be installed in the tool shed and store house he has constructed for use during construction.

With reference to the water supply at this school, Mr. Ferguson has now had a pump installed in the well and it is found considerable gravel or sand has come up in the casing leaving only six or seven feet of water in the casing. It will only supply one pail of water about every four or five minutes which will, unless it improves, be inadequate.

The Driller thinks it may improve with constant use; however, I am rather doubtful and unless it improves greatly during the pouring of the concrete, I would suggest trying to have it deepened. The driller claims he had considerable difficulty getting down the last ten feet on account of boulders and caving in. This would appear to me to indicate we are close to bed rock and it may
be necessary to drill into rock to get an adequate water supply for this school.

Some water was struck at about fifty feet and I considered by putting the casing too deep, we might shut the water out altogether but I am of the opinion now that it requires deepening.

Ref: Lakeview School

I wish to refer to Departmental Letter No. 19-24-5 (E) dated June 4, 1948 with reference to certain changes in specifications from standard.

It is noted insul brick siding is authorized in place of asbestos shingles. This matter was discussed with Mr. Matters on his recent visit to the Agency and Mr. Matters is of the same opinion as the Contractor, Mr. Ferguson, that insul brick siding has a tendency to rot the sheathing, that moisture does not escape and Mr. Ferguson is inclined to believe that the insulation would become damp and would not dry out properly with the use of insul brick siding.

I also note that the purchase order issued to Mrs. Anne Buck for Murray Hill School calls for asbestos shingles so that I would be pleased to have it definitely established which is to be used on each school.

I do not like the appearance of a red siding with a blue roof and if it is decided to use the insul siding, I would suggest using a stone block effect which is now available in white and will give a much better appearance with a blue roof than a red brick siding.

It is also noted the specifications call for urinal troughs and glazed doors on the toilet. I would recommend two upright urinals as much more
sanitary and the cost will be only about $15.00 higher. I would also suggest there should be no glass in the toilet doors.

Mr. Ferguson has written twice to the Cost Audit bureau for the necessary forms to apply for progress payments with no results.

Re: Lakeview School.

We will require a wire fence around this school site, and I have an opportunity to get a good ten line Lindy tight lock fence, two four foot and one twelve foot wire gates with Burlington U-Bar steel posts from J. D. Wilson, who is doing the concrete work on this school.

Mr. Wilson is Agent for the Lindy Fence, and is an expert at erecting wire fence. I would recommend using cedar posts for gates, and corners set in cement with the intermediate posts of steel. The cedar posts soon rot off at the surface of the ground, unless set in cement.

Mr. Wilson makes a very neat job. He would charge $1.00 per hour for his own time, and would employ all Indian labour.

The fence is the best grade obtainable, all No.9 wire, ten wires horizontal, and sixteen wires vertical to the rod. I do not know just what the cedar posts will cost, but they will be purchased from the Indians, and I am enclosing a requisition for the other material to be purchased from Mr. Wilson.

I did not get an estimate from Mr. Wilson on cost of labour, but would put it roughly at $100.00, and would recommend having Mr. Wilson do the work, and be assured of a good neat job.

As I have had some complaint from Mr. Debassige about horses gaining entrance to his farm through the opening at the road, I would recommend having the fence erected with the least possible delay, and would request an advance of $100.00 to pay for labour.

From his recent visit to several schools in your Agency, Mr. Doucet reports the following:

1. Wikwemikong Indian Day School - The school plumbing is leaking between the two floors above the kitchen. The Agent has been authorized to have this checked immediately and the necessary repairs made. The school roof leaks at two places. The Agent has been authorized to have this thoroughly inspected and have the spots where the leakage occurs re-shingled. This may entail a few shingles or a couple of square feet. However, as it is ruining the ceilings and walls, it was necessary to have this done immediately. Ceilings at the spot of leakage will have to be re-plastered. It is not more than a few square feet at each spot.

There is plenty of water in the well but apparently the cylinder of the pump is leaking and would need new leathers. The Agent has been asked to have this done. It should entail very little expense.

The Department confirms the decisions made by Mr. Doucet and wish you to have the above done as soon as possible.

We have received your wire re the condenser and coil for the electrical plant. These articles have been ordered through Fairbanks-Morse and will be forwarded to you as soon as they arrive.

2. West Bay Indian Day School - A great deal of the cold air enters the kitchen from the foundation. This should be thoroughly banked with the surrounding soil in the Fall and in the Spring cleared away to prevent the lumber from decaying. Primes should be obtained immediately from an insulation company on insulating the school and residence.
A storm porch approximately 5'x6' should be built at the entrance of the second classroom.

The Department desires you to obtain prices for this insulation at your earliest convenience and also the cost of building the above mentioned porch.

3. Lakeview and Murray Hill - You are authorized to use the rock siding insul brick instead of the red brick for the Lakeview School and if the Company supplying the asbestos shingles for the siding of the Murray Hill School is willing to substitute the rock insul brick, you are hereby authorized to make this substitution.

Obtain a contract for the forced air stoker fed heating plant for the Lakeview two-room school and the gravity system with the automatic draft controls for the Murray Hill one-room Day School. Have these contracts sent to this office at your earliest convenience so that the construction of these buildings may not be held up by the heating installation.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Dr. Keenleyside:

This will refer to your Minister's recommendation of July 27th, 1948, for authority to exempt William J. Ferguson from the necessity of furnishing a security deposit in connection with the contract awarded to him for the erection of a two room school and attached teachers' quarters on the West Bay Indian Reserve, Manitoulin Island Indian Agency, Ontario.

It would appear that the work to be undertaken in this case is a public work to which section 16 (1) of the Public Works Act applies.

"The Minister, in all cases in which any public work is being carried out by contract, shall take all reasonable care that good and sufficient security is given to and in the name of His Majesty, for the due performance of the work within the amount and time specified for its completion."

In addition, under Section 17, no payment may be made or work commenced until "the requisite security has been given." As the recommendation in question does not disclose that reasonable care has been taken to obtain security or that any "good and sufficient security" is given, and as the Governor in Council is not legally authorized to waive the requirements of this section, the Board were unable to concur in the recommendation as submitted.
Possibly, however, there may be grounds establishing that "reasonable care" has been taken or that "good and sufficient security" exists in a form other than the usual deposit. In the circumstances, the Board have suggested that you might wish to renew this recommendation in the light of the foregoing comments.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) R. B. Bryce,
For Secretary.

Mr. C.R. Johnston,

We have received the quotation on the installation of the heating system at Lakeview Indian Day School. We wish to submit the following for the consideration of the contractor:

1. We do not favour the iron fireman as a stoker. It is a soft coal burner and has caused considerable trouble in homes using them. Here, I refer to reports which I have received from people using them in Ottawa. We definitely prefer the anthracite coal stoker. Enclosed you will find literature describing the Volcano anthracite stoker. The Ottawa representative has written directly to the company to find out if they have any representative in Little Current. If not, we will make arrangements so that Mr. Charlton may obtain one. The stoker uses buckwheat, white ash, the coal that does not clinker. I feel certain that this type can be obtained in Little Current. The pit below the furnace makes cinder removal more convenient.

2. In looking over the plans, we have noticed that it is going to be rather inconvenient to control the heat in the various sections. By this we mean the two classrooms and residence. Each of these three sections should be separate and controlled preferably automatically by means of electric dampers. You can see the necessity of reducing the heat in the classrooms over the week-end and for holidays. On the other hand, it might prove necessary to reduce the heat in the living quarters during the day. This can be efficiently done only by means
of these automatic controls and the installation of a thermostat on each of these sections. That is, one for each classroom and one in the living-room of the teacherage. The increased cost of this installation should not exceed $150. We do not know whether the furnace dealers in Little Current are familiar with this system. It is rather a simple system and is similar to the automatic control in the smoke stack.

3. The implementation of the above would require a different division in the feed ducts from the furnace. One duct should go to the residence and branch off. Another duct for the classroom should branch off so as to isolate each room. The contractor will readily see the necessity for this.

4. We look favourably on the idea of the duct above the blackboards. We would greatly prefer to have these heating ducts in the partition. We realize that this could not be done in the cloakroom but we believe that other simple arrangements could be made for them even putting them in the floor if no other alternative were possible. We realize that the heating Engineers must have some reason for heating the classrooms in this way but we can not readily see this reason. Should it be impossible to carry out our instructions on this point, we would not be too insistent upon it.

We are prepared to endeavour to obtain from our Purchasing Branch, the seventy-five sheets of galvanized iron (3 ft. x 8 ft. 26 gauge) but to do this it will be necessary for the contractor to delete from his contract the price of this material. Otherwise, it would be difficult for us to obtain priority.

We are returning the blueprints so that the plumbing, heating contractor can take note of the various points mentioned above and return to us if possible by return mail his new contract price so that we may submit it over to Head Office for approval.

Encl:

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir,

In compliance with the request of the Department for certain changes to be made in the heating plans shown by GURNEY'S and change of stoker etc., I submit the following:

1. We can supply the "VOLCANO" anthracite coal stoker which will operate on American "White Ash" rice or buckwheat coal. The manufacturers recommend for this installation Model J.E.R. 40 which is a hopper type having a 40 lb. capacity. Instead of the iron fireman mentioned in the original quotation.

At the moment we have very little information on the automatic electric damper controls. However, I believe they are available. And I will arrange to install one for each main lead in conjunction with a room thermostat for each class room and teachers quarters. There will be an additional charge for this of $150.00.

With slight alterations we will be able to separate the leads or feed ducts to facilitate each class room and teachers quarters being separately controlled by above mentioned automatic dampers regarding the duct shown along the wall of the class rooms. I believe that we can change this, and have it run under the floor of the class rooms. That is against the ceiling of the basement, but in the same general location in relation to the class rooms wall. Risers can then be brought up through the wall and outlets installed in the baseboard under the blackboards at floor level. The same number and size of outlets can be used and located at intervals as shown on the blueprints, but in the baseboard. If it is preferred, the registers can be located in the floor rather than in the wall. In either case the duct will require to be well wrapped with asbestos to reduce radiation and draft loss. This will involve extra labour and insulation in the ductwork.

Regarding Galvanized sheets, we will require 150 sheets 36"x 96" X 26 gage instead of the 75 previously mentioned. Due to the fact that supplies I have been expecting to have available are not forthcoming, it will require this much material to make these installations.

The above changes and additions as mentioned above, in accordance with the suggestions of the department, (all other requirements of the contract to remain in the original letter and quotation) will be installed and installed for a total sum of $2975.00 TWENTY-NINE HUNDRED AND SEVENTY-FIVE DOLLARS. The price of 150 sheets of any amount under this figure may be deducted from the quoted price, if they are supplied through the department.

Yours very truly,
[Vernon W. Charlton]

I wish to draw attention to the matter of supplies being shipped in for schools of this Agency.

Quite frequently supplies for schools at West Bay, Sheshgwaning and Sucker Creek Reserves are addressed only to myself at Manitowaning and are delivered to this office by the transfer that carries all freight for Eastern Manitoulin with the result they have to be re-shipped sometimes at considerable expense.

It is therefore very important that the name of the School be designated, particularly for those schools West of Little Current as all freight or express for those schools should be delivered by another Transfer Company and if the name of the school is indicated, it is easily determined which Transfer should make delivery.

I wish particularly to refer to Purchase Order No. 34332 and 34334. The Teacher's Desk has already been delivered to the Residence of the contractor, Mr. W.J. Ferguson of Mindemoya and has to be returned to Lakeview School. Although the chair desks have not yet arrived, it is noted shipping instructions were identical with that of Purchase Order No. 34334.

I would suggest that the name of the school be designated in all cases which would eliminate a great deal of confusion here and unnecessary expense.

G. R. Johnston,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.

Re: Lakeview Indian Day School.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of Department Letter No. 480-5 (E.1) dated October 21, 1949 with reference to construction of the above School.

I have reviewed all the progress claims and accounts with Mr. Ferguson and can find no discrepancies other than some alternations made by the Auditor.

With regard to the earload of cement; this was covered by voucher No. 48-765 dated August 5, 1949 and does not enter into Mr. Ferguson's contract in any way.

I cannot therefore understand why the costs of the cement should be deducted from the amount due Mr. Ferguson.

I also feel that Mr. Ferguson was probably entitled to the 10% on a higher figure than $30,000.00 as when this figure was set as a ceiling, the plans did not call for plumbing, installation of Hydro and a much less elaborate heating system.

Mr. Ferguson borrowed money to finance the project and had it not been for these extras, the total cost would have been very little if any over $30,000.00.

Mr. Ferguson rather feels that he should have been allowed his percentage on the total cost and I consider there is some justification although the auditor would allow the percentage only on $30,000.00.

C.R. Johnston,
Superintendent,

DEER LAKE (U.C.)

To erect log building with lean-to addition for teacher's living quarters $1,200.00

The Deer Lake Band resides at Sandy Lake, located in that part of the Clansboye agency in the province of Ontario. Sandy Lake is situated approximately 360 miles north of Sioux Lookout. No reserve has been surveyed or set aside for these Indians. This band is one of the largest and most self-sustaining in the agency. There are no school facilities provided and the Indians are anxious to have their children receive an education. There are approximately 100 children of school age. Requests have been received from missionaries and representatives of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church for the establishment of a school. The Agent states that a building 22' x 30' with a lean-to 18' x 22' would be sufficiently large to accommodate the children and house the teacher. The building would be of log construction and the Indians would do all the work, if rations were supplied them. The Agent states that he is sure the cost would not exceed $1,200.

March 19th, 1908.

Sir,

Mr. Clark, Teacher of the New School on the Reserve, reported to me that the attendance at his school is so large that he would require some assistance.

It has been decided by the Chiefs and duly reported to you, that the present Teacher at Thomas' School be appointed Assistant to Mr. Clark at the new School, there being two rooms. At the present time the roads are almost impassable, the scholars attending Thomas' School one and one-half mile from the new School would not be able to attend at the present time, besides the new School has not being fully seated on account of an error of James Smart Co. of Brockville, but the balance of the seats have been shipped which are expected daily. The blackboards which were ordered last summer have not all arrived, the slate for one Board is here and the other is shortly expected, until these are completed, I submit it is not wise to close Thomas' School.

Sir,

The Chiefs at their Council meeting on the 6th instant decided to increase the salary of Mr. John Clark, Senior Teacher at the Chawaken School to $400.00 per annum, and Mr. John Miller Junior Teacher to $350.00 per annum. I beg to report on these separately.

Mr. Clark is the Head teacher of the Chawaken School, this is the largest attended school on the Reserve, he has been most successful since his engagement as teacher a few years ago. He has been offered a School in Haldimand at $400.00 per annum and should he leave the Reserve it will be difficult to procure a teacher satisfactory to the people. I beg to recommend that you approve of the Chiefs' decision to fix the salary of Mr. John Clark at $400.00 per annum from the 1st of October.

As to the increase of Mr. John Miller, Junior Teacher, I submit requires careful consideration. Mr. Miller has been engaged as a Teacher at Thomas' School for some years at a salary of $362.50 per annum, he was quite successful. When the Chawaken School was completed, Thomas School, where Mr. Miller was teaching was closed, he was then offered the position as Junior teacher at the Chawaken School under Mr. Clark at a salary of $300.00 which was approved of by you under cover of August 21st last File No. 1866 which was accepted by him. Mr. Miller has no teaching qualification whatever, all the other schools on the Reserve where they have qualified teachers receive $300.00 per annum, they have full charge of the school and the attendance and responsibility much larger and greater.

The Chawaken School is under the control of the Chiefs, while the other schools are under the control of a School Board. If Mr. Miller as Junior Teacher at Chawaken is to receive $300.00 per annum, it is not fair to the other teachers to receive but $300.00, whose responsibility is much greater.

Report of the Six Nations Night School - 1912.

Remarks.

Last year the night school was attended by male pupils only; this year several young women were among the most regular attendants.

There are, however, several young people, mainly youths, in the vicinity, who, for some inexplicable reason show an aversion to, or, more correctly speaking, a negligence in attending the night school. It is clearly understood that the conduct of the pupils has been so decorous that the slightest mention of discipline has never been necessary; and also that the method of treating the various subjects has been made congenial to all by avoiding such recitations and questioning as might in any way be embarrassing to the unlearned or most sensitive pupil. The only solution for the apparent apathy of the indifferent ones is, that they have inherited some of the aboriginal characteristics of their forefathers, by which the youths, after expending their energies during the day in playing with each other in the ancient game of "Snowsnake," choose to spend their evenings about the store of the village store playing the "Lagoo."

But since education has never completely revolutionized any nation in a decade, the time must be bided.

During the season just closed the weather was extremely severe and oftentimes very inclement; still the attendance and interest in the work never flagged, but rather increased as the season advanced. The assiduity of some was marvellous.

Dear Sir,

On the 18th ult., I received notification from Deputy Mr. Gordon J. Smith, Brampton, that a charge had been made by Chief Lawrence Jonathan in the Six Nations Council that I had been selling intoxicants to the Indians on the Reserve, and that the School Board would investigate the said charge on the 25th ult. at Ohsweken.

I met the School Board upon the day set and found that Chief Lawrence Jonathan had been made a tool of by three malicious and unscrupulous Indian Brothers viz., David S. Hill, Albert E. Hill, and Erno Hill. It was simply a diabolical conspiracy, the nature of which I will give after stating the case:

1. The informer knew nothing but hearsay and even then perjured himself in attempting to screen himself from being implicated in the collective manufacture of the case.

2. David S. Hill knew nothing but hearsay.

As to the motive for the conspiracy:
During the time I inspected the schools of the Reserve I observed and learned:

1. Mr. Alvin J. Scott, a young man who had for years taught No. 9 School with success and satisfaction was, about a year ago, subjected to complaints that he was too intimate with certain Indian women. Mr. Scott wrote to Capt. Smith asking for an investigation which was never given. He left the Reserve shortly after with the stain upon his character although those who knew him best believed him to be guiltless of the charge. There was also some shadowy manipulation about Mr. Scott's salary.

2. Mr. Jas. A. Keays, B.A., taught during the Sept.-Dec. term of 1912 at No. 7 Six Nations School. Members of this same Hill family and another (Jamieson) family circulated stories of Mr. Keays' immorality with Indian women. He left at Xmas. Mr. Keays afterwards wrote to me from Toronto saying that he had not received his salary in full.

3. Mr. A. J. Abbott, assistant teacher at No. 2 Six Nations School up to June 1913, was...
an experienced and energetic teacher.

At the June (1913) meeting of the Six Nations School Board, Chief Hilton M. Hill, clerk at the Indian Office, Brantford, and a brother of the three who were to testify against me, attempted to interpose some gossip complaints about Mr. Abbott. The board appealed to me, being present, for explanation. The complaints were not in any tangible form when I asked for them; in fact were just in the "weaving" and being totally unfounded were not entertained.

A few nights after, David J. Hill, above mentioned, apparently in a well-advanced state of intoxication appeared on the street close to my residence and in the presence of several persons, railed at Mr. Abbott claiming that he was unqualified, incapable etc., and also assailed me for defending him in the School Board meeting. Mr. Abbott left. (It is significant that Mr. Abbott, like myself, was a married man and the charge of trafficking with Indian women would not suit as well as in the case of the other (single) victims).

In each of the above mentioned

Sir: Illness of Miss Nora Jamieson Teacher No. 2 Jr. Room.

As I have previously reported to the Department, Miss Nora Jamieson was taken ill near the end of October and has been in the Brantford General Hospital under the care of Dr. Morrison ever since.

Upon Miss Jamieson being taken ill I appointed Mrs. Mildred Hunter (nee Mildred Froman, late one of our teachers) to take her place at No. 2 School temporarily pending further information from Dr. Morrison as to the probable duration of Miss Jamieson's illness.

I have now received a certificate from Dr. Morrison that Miss Jamieson was discharged from the Hospital to her home on November 24th but that he has ordered her complete rest for three months, before resuming her duties as teacher.

Under these circumstances I am notifying Mrs. Hunter that her services as temporary teacher will no longer be required after the end of this month and am taking from the head of the waiting list, Miss Mary Anderson of Ohsweken, who recently qualified at Normal.

I have not mentioned any specified fee as yet to Miss Anderson who I understand, holds an Interim first class certificate.
I am inquiring from her for definite information. If this is correct, I presume she will start at $1000.00 per annum.

As Miss Jamieson will be away for a further three months I would ask the Department whether it is intended to grant her sick leave on full pay for this period, which including the time of her absence while in the Hospital, will amount to about four months.

The Chiefs at their Council meeting held on 7th August last decided to build a new School House at Onswekon, as the present building is inadequate and badly in need of repair. They also appointed a committee to visit the various School Houses among the white settlement. The Committee reported at a subsequent meeting and recommended the adoption of the School building similar to that in the village of Mountpleasant.

The Architect of the Mountpleasant School building, Mr. G.F. Hall of this City, the proposed building to cost some $4000.00. Mr. Hall asks the sum of $100.00 for preparing Plan and Specifications, half to be paid when Plans are completed and the balance at the completion of the building.

The Chiefs on the 3rd instant decided to accept Mr. Hall's proposal and pay him the sum of $100.00 for Plan and Specifications. I enclose his proposition together with dimensions of building and beg to recommend that you approve of the Chiefs decision to have the School House erected at Onswekon at the cost of some $4000.00, which the Chiefs recommend be paid out of Capital account.

I believe that the building proposed to be erected is suitable for the Reserve, there being two rooms so in time it can be used as a graded school, which I believe shortly will be required at Onswekon, and further to recommend that I be instructed to have Mr. Hall prepare Plan and Specifications at the cost of $100.00 and forward same to you when received.

Mr Agent Cameron, under cover of a letter of the 18th instant, forwards plans and specifications prepared by Mr Hall, architect of Brantford for a new schoolhouse proposed to be erected at Ohweken at a cost of about $4000.00.

take possession at the opening after summer holidays, and the Council also instructed the Inspector of Works to stake out the spot where the well is to be situated, and the Inspector of Works is hereby authorized to call in tenders as soon as possible for digging said well.

The Council decided to ask Mr. Rupert Cameron to write to the Commissioner of Indian Affairs Washington in behalf of the reserve land claims. According to Buffalo Creek treaty in 1838, the Court of Claims decided that the New York State Indians and their descendants were to be the participants in the distribution of the reserve money. The Tuscaroras and other Indians of the State of New York are opposing the rights of Canadian Indians who are descendants of the New York State Indians, so he wrote Delegate and attended the meeting in 1838 at Buffalo Creek when the treaty was signed. There are also women members of the Tuscarora band of this Reserve, who have married members of the Lewiston band N.Y., who have ceased to be members of this band who have forfeited all...
their rights to the distribution of lands and other benefits here, but whom the Tuscaroras at Seneca N.Y. refuse to place them on their enrollment. The Six Nations Council therefore request that the Commissioner of Indian Affairs might be pleased to place these people and their children on the roll in like manner as the Canadian Government does with women coming from Seneca and other Reservations in New York State and marrying into our band. Women coming from Reservations in the United States marrying into Six Nations band become together with their children full members of the band, and are entitled to share equally in lands and annuity money, the same as other members of the Six Nations in Canada.

On receipt of your letter of 14th December last, file No. 164 888/5 I informed Mr. Hill that his tender for digging a wall on the school premises at Chawanak at $1.00 per foot was approved, and asked him to proceed with the work as soon as possible.

At the Council meeting held on the 11th instant, Mr. Hill applied to the Council for some change in the specifications; the Chiefs refused to grant any, he then informed the Chiefs that he would be unable to carry out his contract. The Chiefs then accepted the next tender being Joseph Porter's at $1.20 per foot. I notified Mr. Porter of the Chiefs' decision and now have received his reply, that he is prepared to carry out his contract.

I therefore beg to recommend under the circumstances that Joseph Porter's tender at $1.20 per foot be approved and the work be proceeded with as soon as possible, as water will be required as soon as the weather will permit Levi Jonathan to begin the building of the new school house at Chawanak.

Sir,

The Chiefs at their Council meeting held on the 10th instant decided to lay the corner stone of their new school house at Chippewa on the 26th instant.

Sir,

Chawahan New School.

Mr. Augustus Jamieson, Inspector of Works, reported to the Council, that he would not be able to complete the building for the amount left at his disposal, or Chief Jonathan's tender.

Had Jonathan been spared to complete the building he would have been able to do so at the contract price, he being a thorough mechanic and would have teamed the lumber, sand, gravel and lime required and done most of the carpenter work, all of which Mr. Jamieson was obliged to employ and obliged to pay more for teaming than it was expected, on account of the heavy harvest teams were scarce.

The Chiefs decided to continue the work until the contract price of Chief Jonathan is expended, when tenders will be asked for the balance and the same paid out of their interest accounts. The building will be completed according to the plan and specifications with money on hand with the exception of the blackboards and the double spring hinges for the inner swing doors. I am unable to learn the price of the slate blackboards, the hinges will cost some $30.00, outside of hinges and blackboards the cost will not be over $25.00. As the Council is anxious to have the School opened on the 25th instant, I beg to ask for authority to have the slate blackboards put in and the hinges referred to purchased and building completed as mentioned above, providing the cost does not exceed what I have mentioned, so there can be no delay in completing the building. As soon as tenders are received for the work will forward same to you.

I

It was reported to me by the Trustees of the School at Ohsweken, that the frost was doing damage to the basement of the new School, and on consulting with Mr. G. W. Hall, the Architect, he advised that a fire at once be started and kept in the new School. At the same time the building occupied as a School at Ohsweken was badly in need of repairs and was uncomfortable for the scholars. In order to save the expense of keeping two fires in two buildings, the School Trustees in consultation with me as well as a number of the Chiefs, thought better to have the benches now used at the old School at Ohsweken removed to the new building where School could be held in one of the rooms, which would be comfortable for the scholars, thereby saving the expense of keeping fire in the old School at Ohsweken. Coal was ordered from here; the above accounts include the expenses of teaming coal from here to Ohsweken over 10 miles and transferring the benches from the old School to the new one. The seats which were ordered some months ago from James Smart Co., Brockville, have not arrived.

To the Right Reverend

Schools

JUN 13 1904

Some weeks ago the Six Nations council called for tenders for the building of a side walk in front of the new school house at Ohsweken, known as the Six Nations School. David Davis being the successful tender for the work at $55.00 which you are aware I have not done anything at the work yet. The trustees brought the matter before the chief in council on Tuesday June 7th asking them if they should have the plans changed. The trustees suggested a circular instead of a bow front fashion as the contract call for a side plan you will find enclosed this. The trustees proposed the said change but our C.D. Cameron the chief thought this could not be done without your authority. In the matter stands as it is unless you can see your way clear to authorize the proposed change which would make a great improvement to the appearance of the front of our school house. We trust therefore that you will give the matter your consideration. We are your humble servant.

Chief J.S. Johnson

Dear Sir,

This is to certify that I have examined the sidewalks on the new school grounds at Okanagan, and find the work is completed in a proper and workmanlike manner by Mr. David Davis, but the sleepers or joints are partly used with sap pine which is not according to specification nor the Department's preference.

Inspector of Works.
I beg to enclose account of David Burke amounting to $385.00 covering work building side walls of the Cheyenne School, which was duly authorized by your letter of 16th December last, file no. 195 (884).

I attach to the account statement of Mr. Augustus Johnson, Inspector of Works on the Reserve, your bill showing an estimate of $285.00 for some pine siding, when the specifications called for white pine.

The undersigned Burke assure me that nothing but white pine was used. When I notified him that the tender was accepted, the Inspector informed me that it would be impossible if the siding were of cedar or oak in place of the white pine. Mr. Burke applied to the various lumber firms, but could not procure any lumber could get a 1 x 6 inch siding, but Mr. Johnson, the Inspector, would accept nothing smaller than 4 x 6 dimension. Mr. Burke, taking the specifications to a most reliable firm, Mr. Smith, located a lot where he received the materials in accordance with the specifications. Some 30 miles were taken to the grounds which is some 12 miles from here. Mr. Johnson would not accept them, claiming they were not white pine. Burke assured him they were white pine from Montana.

Mr. Johnson called at the time Mr. Smith, manager of the firm, assured him that there were white pine, but stating that any difference between Mr. Johnson and Mr. Smith had asked Mr. Johnson to set aside that he considered our white pine.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, July 14, 1909.

The Acting Deputy Minister,

The Six Nation Council called for tenders for painting the Ohsweken school-house. Three offers were received, and they have accepted Mr. Albert W. Hill's tender for $114.50, which was the lowest.

The Six Nation schools will open on Aug. 16 after the summer holidays, and as there are about 100 pupils enrolled at this school it should be ready for occupation then.

If the tenders have to be submitted to His Excellency the Governor in Council, there would hardly be time to have the work done by the date above mentioned, and as this is a case of pressing emergency and the amount involved is small and the work will be done by the lowest tenderer, I think that Mr. Hill might be authorized to proceed with the painting. The cost will be paid out of band funds.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

Bennett & Bowden account.

The Council of the Six Nations on Aug. 9th, 1913 authorized certain repairs to a number of schools on the reserve among the number being school No. 2, and a list of the repairs considered necessary, made out by Messrs Jamieson and Hill, which, however, does not mention all the repairs actually done, is also on file. This was approved by the Dept. on Aug. 15th.

The next correspondence is an extract from the minutes of a meeting of the Council of Jan. 6th., 1914, when the Council again postponed consideration of the account for these repairs made by Messrs Bennett & Bowden, but instructed the Fire Inspectors to examine the work and account and report. This they did at a meeting on the 29th. Jan. 1914. Their report stated that the charges were excessive, and after much discussion the Council unanimously decided to confirm this report. The original account was for $409.75, and the Inspectors cut it down to $250.50 - a difference of $159.75.

Chief Johnson, writing on Jan. 23rd. through Mr. Cockshutt, charges the Council with unduly cutting down the account, and gives as reason for their doing so the opinion...
that the Council took this means of discouraging the giving of work on the reserve to white men. He stated that the Council during the last few years had authorized the Inspector of Works to have odd repairs made to the school, and these jobs had gone to the friends of the Inspector, with the result that the repairs had been both insufficient and badly done.

Mr. Superintendent Smith in his report of Feb. 2nd, gives his opinion that a good many of the statements made by Mr. Johnson could not be borne out by facts. He points out that one item in the Bennett & Bowden account is for $54.50 for board. Mrs. Johnson, when asked how much she received, finds only $9.50 while Bennett & Bowden were working on the school,- but Mr. Smith adds that there was a further amount (he does not say how much) for board during the time the contractors were working on the Church. The contractors claim that the whole of this amount was paid Mrs. Johnson, and ask that the account be investigated, as good value had been given for material and work.

The Superintendent submits that the Council had done only a little patchwork from time to time, and that though it would have been better to call for tenders for painting the building, Mr. Johnson was justified in having the steps, doors and wall repaired immediately. Mr. Smith states in conclusion that the Council had reduced the account too much, as the work appeared to have been well done, and the appearance of the building was much improved in consequence.

Moved by Mr. Park and seconded by Chief Lottridge that this School Board accepts with much regret Mr. Standing's resignation and in the meantime till some definite arrangement of the matter may be found Mr. J. Clark be requested to inspect the schools of the Reserve.

Indian Office, Brantford,
November 1st., 1912.

Moved by Rev. Geo. Carpenter and seconded by Chief Lottridge that as it is impossible to get an outside School Inspector at the present time we appoint Mr. John Clark to inspect the schools for one year at $200.00 per annum from Nov. 1st, 1912 to Nov. 1st, 1913 on condition Mr. Clark will make satisfactory arrangements with the chairman of the Board to have his own school inspected by another person and supply a proper teacher for his school while on duty as inspector also in the meantime we ask the Department to supply an outside Inspector for the following year. JOHN CLARKE

Re Lawrence Jonathan's Charge.

The following is the evidence as taken before Mr. Charles McGibbon, in the Indian Office, Brantford, Ont., on December 17th, 1913, at 2:30 p.m.

COUNSEL: Mr. W. A. Hollinske, for Plaintiff.

EVIDENCE

Mr. John Clark, sworn, examined by MR. HOLLINSKE:

I am a teacher on the reserve. I was appointed 14 years ago. I have been teaching there ever since with the exception of four months. For a year and four months I was Inspector of Schools on the Reserve. I am not Inspector now. The School Board relieved me, for reasons best known to themselves. I had ten or eleven teachers under me; some were qualified and some were not. I believe Mr. Scott's case was the first one there. He was there at the time I took charge. He was a very successful teacher. He was not qualified; he had two or three years experience. There were some complaints about him. He has sent in an affidavit here. (Reads). A year ago today I believe I attended a meeting of the Six Nations School Board, and heard the resolution moved, seconded and passed that that increase began the 1st of January. I have also letters from Mr. Scott that he was subject to damning complaints, and he asked for an investigation that was never given. I claim that this persecution was brought upon for a purpose since a friend of Chief Hilton Hill's was put in the school since he left. I believe A. O. Smith is the Secretary of the School Board, and that that resolution was passed a year ago today. Scott left because they did not carry out the recommendations of the School Board, and Miss Russell, a lady who lives close to the school, took his place.

I remember the increase of some of the salaries. I do not remember anyone taking objection and stating that the matter should be referred to the new Board. A. G. Smith, sworn, examined by: MR. McGIBBON:

I am a member of the school Board of 1913. I was not a member of the Board of 1912. That question (reads resolution) came up and was discussed at either the first or second meeting of the Board, I forget just which. The discussion was on account of misunderstanding of the resolution being passed that increases be made in the salaries of Scott and Lickers, I believe. Part of the members of the Board claimed that it was passed, and then we looked in the Minutes as it was copied, and I found it was indefinite because it was simply written. Moved and Seconded that the increase be made to the salaries of these people without stating whether that motion was carried or not, and then I went back to look at the original which was written in pencil. Jamieson appeared to have been acting Secretary at that time, and he did not state in the Minutes as to whether it was carried. Peter Jamieson expressed himself as being under the impression that it was carried or on second thought, that it was referred to the new Board that was to be elected. It seemed to be pretty well understood that it was carried. I knew nothing of it because I was not a member of the old Board. After thinking for a while Jamieson was under the impression that it was referred to the new Board. I did not remember whether April was the first meeting or the second meeting.

To MR. HOLLINRANE: That was the only discussion I think; I don't think there was anything said after that. I cannot be sure whether the matter was discussed at the first meeting of the new Board.
I think the matter was only discussed once.

MR. CLARKE: The second case was the case of Mr. Kees, and he beside being subject to defamation of character of which there are several witnesses to bear testimony, he was also subject to blackmail and a threat of assault.

To MR. McGIBBON: I for one heard Mr. Hill circulating defamatory stories about Mr. Kees.

To MR. HOLLINRAKE: As to his morality. He had also asked Mr. Smith to prosecute the man who threatened to assault him.

Robert Martin, sworn, examined by MR. CLARKE:

About a year ago I heard defamatory stories about Mr. Keys, teacher of #7. They were some stories which were not very nice. I heard Mr. Will Curry speak of it, and Mr. David Jamieson made a few remarks and Albert Hill.

MR. HOLLINRAKE: I never heard that there was any truth in them, none that I know of.

David Davis, sworn, examined by MR. CLARKE:

About a year ago I heard them talking disrespectfully about Mr. Kees, teacher of No. 7, that he was not conducting himself very well at the school. I heard this from Mr. Albert Hill.

To MR. McGIBBON: I could not say whether these stories were true.

MR. CLARKE (To Mr. McGibbon) In a letter I have from Mr. Scott he claimed that the same stories had been circulated about him, and he asked Mr. Smith for an investigation of the matter, but it was never given. I have the letter.

The next case was of Mr. Abbott, a qualified experienced teacher in #2 School.

Rev. Mr. Park, sworn, examined by MR. CLARKE:

In the June meeting of the Six Nations School Board of the
present year I remember some complaints being brought up against Mr. Abbott. Mr. Hilton Hill said there were complaints against Mr. Abbott's conduct and character. There was nothing much done, but I said I considered Mr. Abbott a very first-class teacher and that the children were fond of him, and there was nothing very definite and no resolution passed, some of them were blaming him, and Mr. Abbott told me some time before that he was not going to stand it, and the result was he left. He resigned and I am sorry. I considered that he was an acquisition to the schools on the reserve, and conducting himself properly. He roamed right next to the Rectory, and I was very sorry to hear that Mr. Abbott had gone, and I was quite satisfied that that was why he left, that people had been discrediting him.

TO MR. McGIBBON: Mr. Hilton Hill made the report that he was not conducting himself properly. I think someone asked what was the nature of these complaints and there was nothing definite. I was surprised, not surprised in a measure, but I was surprised at Mr. Abbott; I was not surprised at the party these things came from, for I had been maligned myself, but I concluded it was not worth the trouble and I let it rest. In fact, I didn't know I could do anything, I thought I had to submit.

J. S. Johnson, sworn, examined by MR. McGIBBON:
There was never any complaint of him that I know of except that of some words of expression mentioned against him. This was outside. In the June meeting I don't remember anything. I cannot remember any complaints about Mr. Abbott being discussed.

A. G. Smith, sworn, examined by MR. CLARKE:
I am afraid I am ignorant on the subject of the complaints against Mr. Abbott which came up at the June meeting. I am a little afraid I missed that meeting.
Chief A. G. Elliott, sworn, examined by MR. CLARKE:

During last summer I heard some complaints about Mr. Abbott teacher of School #2. They were given by David S. Hill. He said that Mr. Abbott was no good as a teacher, that he was away behind the times, that he was not qualified, and that we should have a qualified teacher at that school. He also said that other teachers of the Reserve were not qualified. He said that you should be out of that, and quite recently he made the remark that he would have John Clarke out by Christmas.

David S. Hill made that remark. He had something to say about you bringing in constables to look after the whiskey question during the fair. He said you were the cause of bringing the Dominion police down to inspect the Reserve during fair time. I don't recollect that he said anything about who was to pay for it. I don't remember that he said it was at the expense of the nation.

MR. CLARKE (To MR. MCGIBBON) Now in the case of Miss Almas, teacher of #7; in the June meeting of the Six Nations there was a resolution passed I think, that her salary should be paid at the rate of $400.00. That was the meeting of June 1913. Motion read.

I understood from Miss Almas that her salary was to be $500.00 and I have understood since that she was paid at the rate of $500.00, contrary to that resolution. I understood that she had a claim of $600.00, but that the School Board authorized payment at the rate of $400.00, though they afterwards, I believe, overlooked that resolution and extra money was paid. I do not know on what authority Mr. Strong would issue that cheque. This was last June.

Jerome Duncan, sworn, examined by MR. CLARKE:

Last winter one night I was present on the street with Knox Hill when he was drunk. We did not wait outside of your house for some time. I did not stand and linger there for some
time. I never went past a second time. We did not pass the house more than once a little after midnight, that I can remember.

I did not halt at all. Know Hill did not wait. We never followed a party that came out of your house, with the intention of assaulting him. I was with the person who intended to assault you. It was another fellow, about half past twelve or something like that, who passed Mr. Clarke's. We had come out of the pool room, and it was about between David Garlow's and George Miller's. I was not following the fellow. I do not know what the other fellow followed him for. When we got up to this fellow, he said Good-night. The man I was with was under the influence of liquor. I do not know that he was waiting and walking around the streets looking for a chance to lick somebody.

Q—To threaten the party that came out of my house with assault? A—They both threatened one another. I did not follow with Know over the road. He went to the corner of the Council House, and I stood by the gate. I don't know that I went out of my way. I just wanted to hear what was on.

George Curry, sworn, examined by MR. CLARKE:

During the past few months or a year I have heard of several threats of assault. One was by David Hill. He called you some pretty names, and said he could lick you anywhere at any time. I must say that Mr. Clarke is the best teacher they have had. He was the one who educated the Hill and Jamieson family, then they were done with him.

MR. SMITH: I agree with what you say about Mr. Clarke.

I have heard during the last few months or a year back of you being assaulted. You would have been lots of times if you

I heard Mr. David Hill talking about it.

I am a chief. I do not know that I could make you understand, as I cannot take the English. I would sooner have somebody to interpret. (To interpreter) Q—Some time ago this man made a charge against Mr. Clarke for supplying liquor to Indians? A—Yes; I was simply told that that was the report. David Hill and Albert Hill told me. Dear Mr. Scott,

Referring to your letter to me dated Dec 3/13, I have enclosed a report that I held an investigation into the matter in question and have attached the evidence taken for your information.

I am unable to find that Mr. Clark has any grievance in this case; as it appears to me the trouble arises from the fact of the Catlow Board engaging another inspector for the agency and the inspector for the schools. According to the Resolution, copy of which I enclose, Mr. Clark was only engaged for one year.

I am firmly of the opinion that had Mr. Clark not been engaged to inspect the schools in 1912, the trouble would have resulted.

The reappointment of Mr. Standing as County Inspector seems to have been a great disappointment to Mr. Clarke, in fact, to see how he could be expected to inspect the schools and give proper attention to his own school at Oshawa. The fact of him holding two positions displeased certain decisions in his school section and helped on the trouble.

Mr. Clarke complains about reports started about other teachers being afraid these reports are much too common on Indian Reserves and it is a hard matter to meet the difficulty unless the report complaints of sufficiently serious to warrant bringing the offender before a magistrate.

I warned the people at the investigation that it was a most outrageous offence to circulate stories that would injure any...
any Person standing in the Community,

The Clerk appears to be a Good Teacher and a Clear Man but of fancy lacks tact and is not too Pacific in disposition.

I pointed this out to him and I submit the hope that matters will move more along more smoothly.

I would suggest that the Capt be instructed to keep the original copies of the resolutions of all School Board meetings being them away in his office so that at any time they can be referred to in case of a dispute as to the correct wording of a recorded Resolution.

Sir,

I beg to report that I have made inspection of school house No. 2 at Ohsweken, Six Nations Reserve.

I found this building to be in a dangerous condition. Owing to the settling of the stone foundation walls the exterior walls are gradually bulging towards the outside, with the result that the joists on the ground floor are resting only a few inches on the wooden beams under the centre of the class rooms. The roof and eaves troughs are also in need of repairs.

I would recommend that the Superintendent be authorized to have the whole of the plastered ceiling which is in a poor condition in the basement removed, and that all the joists be bolted together. It is also necessary that the walls be straightened out, and tied together by means of steel rods with turned buckles. While the carpenters are there, I would suggest that they examine the upper part of the building by raising the floors, etc., in order to find out if any similar work is required above the ground floor.

I estimate that the cost of the above mentioned work will be about $480.

Departmental Engineer.
