Dear Sir:

"Sinking foundation of No. 2 School"

I beg to report that acting upon instructions received from you today, inspected No. 2 school at Ohsweken, the foundation of which is sinking and has been reported as unsafe.

I found the joists on the main floor drawing off the beams, there being evidence of recent movement. I inspected the joists in the roof and found that some of these had also slightly drawn but not so much as those on the main floor, nor apparently as recently.

About twelve months ago tie rods were installed and as a pronounced movement has since taken place it has been assumed that these rods were not doing their work. Upon inspection, however, I found that the bolts and plates on the outer ends of these rods were loose and the plates were not functioning at all.

The trouble is caused by the subsidence of the foundations which is greatly due to seepage of water between the wall and the ground outside and also, I understand, that when the building was put up the foundation trenches were dug too deep and subsequently filled in with loose rubble to the required depth. I found that the cement work around the water pipes was full of holes and apparently most of the water from the roof is running down alongside the foundations.

I am of opinion that there is no immediate danger if proper precautions are taken.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6223, file 483-5, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
I recommend:

1. That the rods be immediately tightened all over.
2. That the cement around the water pipes outflows on the ground be repaired.
3. That all outside cracks be pointed and carefully watched.
4. That marked wedges be put in the existing openings between the joists and the beams and carefully watched.
5. That the bearing of the cellar joists be increased by spiking pieces of 2" x 4" to them.
6. That the loose bricks on the top of the chimney be removed and the window and door arches be re-keyed and re-pointed and watched.

I do not think that the tendency of the wall on the north west corner to bulge is sufficiently serious not to be counteracted by the tie rods after they are kept properly tightened, and if there was any tendency to fall inwards, which there is not it would be stayed by the joists.

The suggestions which I now make are, of course, temporary to tide over the winter but I think that the whole question of the condition of the foundation of this school should be gone into as soon as mason work becomes practical in the spring when it will be a question for the Departmental Architect to decide whether the school should come down or be jacked up and the foundation rendered safe.

Finally I would add that you visited the Reserve with me where we met Mr. Albert Hill, who I understand built No. 6 & 11 schools and who has undertaken that these measures by me shall be at once carried out.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Orr:

"No. 2 School Six Nations Reserve".

It has been reported to me that the wedges, which were placed in various positions in No. 2 school last fall on instructions from Mr. Brock to detect any further subsidence, are again moving.

The general thaw has now set in accompanied by the usual amount of surface water which finds its way into the foundations and I am not sure whether this building is safe for occupation. MEMORANDUM:

Mr. McLean,

I have to report that on Friday afternoon last I met the members of the Indian Council at the No. 2 school at Ohweken, and made an inspection of this building. As I previously reported the school is in an unsafe condition, due partly to settlement of the foundation and partly to poor construction. The outside walls are of solid brick and are only eight inches thick. The result is that they are bulging badly in many places. I discussed two schemes with the Indian Council in connection with this building, first the demolishing of the old building and the building of a new school; second the tearing down of the outside walls of the school and rebuilding same in balloon frame construction. The latter is more economical and I believe the best system to adopt.

I would recommend that Col. Morgan be instructed to lay the matter officially before the Council at their next meeting, and obtain a minute authorizing the expenditure from their band funds amounting to approximately $3,500.00 to make the necessary repairs.

ARCHITECT.
August 24, 1925.

Sir,

The Architect of the Department who visited Brantford recently has again reported that the No 2 School at Chateaugay is in an unsafe condition, due to settlement of the foundation and to the bulging of the outside walls, caused by the brickwork in the walls being only eight inches thick, which is not sufficient for walls of their height with the number of window openings in same. It has been recommended that there are two schemes which could be adopted in connection with the remodelling of this building; first, to totally demolish the building and rebuild anew, or to remove the outside walls and rebuild on a concrete foundation and balloon frame construction above. The latter would be the most economical, and could probably be done for approximately $3,500.00.

I would ask you to bring this matter to the attention of the Indian Council at their next meeting for the necessary action.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

I beg to report that on Wednesday of last week I made an inspection of the No 2 School now being repaired on the Six Nations Reserve at Brantford. As previously reported on the 14th, instructions were given to the Indians employed on the work to rebuild the outside walls, care being taken to put the necessary supports in the interior of the building to provide temporary support for the roof. Unfortunately, when they commenced operations the building was in such poor condition that it collapsed, while in Brentford I took the necessary measurements in the morning, and in the afternoon Mr. Fairchild of Brantford granted me use of his office and I prepared a plan for the building of the school on the same foundation. The new building will be of balloon frame construction, and provision is made for two classrooms, a cloak room, etc. The classrooms will be slightly larger than the former ones. We will use as much of the old material as possible. The work is being carried out by day labour, and Mr. Wilson Russell, an Indian on the Reserve, who is a competent mechanic, is acting as foreman. The Indians have passed a resolution authorizing the expenditure of $4,000.00 from their band funds for this work.

Ottawa,

Dear Mr. Orr:

"Re No. 2 school."

Mr. Russell is about through with the work all but the painting. He has only four men working now. When he was in he mentioned about the furnaces and the registers. The furnaces will have to be turned on account of the chimneys being in a different place than where they were before. These furnaces are the Kelseys and were installed by Turnbull and Sons of this City. Please let me know what you want done with regard to the above.

The roads on the Reserve are impassable with a car, the side roads are regular quagmires and it is raining again today.
There is a lot of material left over, odds and ends, and Mr. Russell reported that a lot of old lumber was disappearing. Mr. Montour, Inspector of Works, has advertised for a sale of the material next Thursday. This is our Council day.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

HH/B.
Nov. 23, 1926.

Dear Col. Morgan,

Replying to your letter of the 26th instant, with reference to the new No. 2 School, I would ask you to please arrange with Turnbull and Sons of Brantford, who originally installed the hot air furnace at the No. 2 School, to make the necessary changes in the installation, as required by the alterations in the layout of the building.

I expect to be in Brantford some day next week.

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

Lt. Col. O. H. Morgan,
Six Nations,
Brantford, Ont.

The Board, therefore, recommend that authority be granted for the expenditure of $4000.00 from the capital funds of the band, which now amount to $559,588.72, for the said purpose, pursuant to the provisions of Section 89 of the Indian Act.

MEMORANDUM

Dr. Scott,

In December last an Order in Council provided $4,000.00 for the erection of No.2 School-house on Six Nations Reserve. As the work was under way before the Order in Council was obtained, $1,000.00 was advanced from Interest funds and an expenditure of $3,906.67 has already been made against the amount provided by Council. Unpaid accounts amounting to $1775.82 are now before the Department, and before dealing with them I would be glad to know whether additional funds will be provided by Order in Council from Capital, or should these be paid from Interest. The accounts before the Department to date exceed the $4,000.00 provided by $2,685.49.

The Capital Funds of Six Nations is now $656,014.45, and the Interest is $12,749.95.

Chief Accountant.
MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the cost of rebuilding the No. 2 School at Ohsweken on the Six Nations Reserve, in my memorandum to you of the 14th of September I estimated the cost at approximately $3,500.00. At that time it was the intention to rebuild the unsafe outside brick walls without removing the roof, or disturbing the foundation. When work was commenced, however, through unforeseen conditions the building collapsed, and it was, therefore, necessary to rebuild the entire school, which of course doubled the cost. The work has been done in a satisfactory manner and the Department has excellent value for the money expended.

Sir,

"Re-erection of No.2 School
Six Nations Reserve."

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental Letter No.32-2-5-A of the second instant.

From this, and previous correspondence, it appears to be thought in the Department that the erection of this building was under my supervision, and the purchase of materials in connection with it in my hands which was not the case.

This work was started late in the year, when the roads were impassable, and the only possible course, if the work was to be finished in time for occupation by the pupils after the Christmas holidays, was to leave it in the hands of the Foreman of Works, Mr Wilson Russell.

The Departmental Architect realized this and instructed Mr Russell to proceed with the work giving him such instructions as regards material paint and the roofing as he considered necessary.
It is claimed continuously both before the work was commenced and during its operation and it would not have been possible for Mr. Orr to reach the reserve in a car had he visited Brantford.

Mr. Fairchild and I, as well as the Inspector of works visited the work during its progress but the work and the selection and purchase of materials were in Mr. Russell's hands.

Mr. Orr has, I believe, full confidence in Mr. Russell, who built the R.C.M.P. Barracks at No. 6 School and No. 11 with Albert Hill.

I have interviewed the firms of Turnbull and Cutcliffe and Turnbull and Sons and obtained explanations from them of the items queried which I attach marked A & B.

I will answer the queries contained in Departmental letter 32-2-5-4 in the order in which they appear in the letter.

The two School Furnaces.

The charge appears excessive until the work done is considered. These furnaces had been disconnected. The casing, air pipes and various fittings had been battered and broken by the children who have been allowed to play in the cellars, which has now been stopped. Bars, doors and other castings required renewal.

While the building was occupied by the builders it was not possible to dismantle and re-erect them, so that the building was finished and ready for occupation before work on the furnaces could be started.

Indifferent warmth was provided for the workmen by hired stoves but the furnaces delayed occupation by the pupils for two weeks after school reassembled.

Upon examination before moving them into their new positions in
conformity with the new building, they were found to be falling to pieces. I wrote to the Departmental Architect who instructed me to get into touch with the agents for the makers, which I did.

As Turnbull and Sons are the only agents for the makers in Brantford, as far as I am aware, and the spare parts had to come from the makers, no good end would have been served by calling for tenders from other firms, who would have been obliged to obtain their parts from Turnbull and Sons.

It became a question of either buying new furnaces, which would have cost $300.00 each F.O.B. Brockville, plus pipes and other extras and cost of erection, or having these repaired.

They have been rebuilt with new cases, doors, bars, pipes and ventilators, and are every bit as good as new, and are reported on as being entirely satisfactory.

For information regarding the motor transport and other detail please see Turnbull and Sons letter marked A.

Turnbull and Cutcliffe.

Tenders were not called for the reason I have given above.

The paint supplied to Mr Russell was Brandon Henderson's best quality and not that tendered earlier in the year for other work.

The quotations then made were at wholesale rates and Mr Russell took out with him each pay day as much as he could carry in his rig to last until he came in again.

The difference between $5.25, for half a gallon and $6.00, for a gallon is customary when smaller containers are bought.

The difference in putty has been credited, although there was some
fluctuation in the white lead market which led to it, I understand.

The difference in prices charged for nails - 7¢ and 5¢ is owing to
difference in quality, the higher being for finishing nails.

Sixteen brushes to paint the area involved, with a number of painters
employed simultaneously is not excessive, and there were also brushes
for varnish and staining the desks.

No doubt these brushes, or such as have not been worn out, are in
the possession of the Superintendent of Works on the Reserve whose
business it is to care for such things, I will enquire and furnish a
report.

The Departmental Architect desired this particular type of roof which
is only supplied in this district, as far as I am aware, by the Brant
Roofing Company, whose agents are Turnbull and Cutcliffe.

For the full explanation desired by the Department, I would refer to
the Departmental Architect and to the letter from the agents, marked B.

It was, I understand, arranged that when the building was ready for the
roof Mr Russell was to communicate with Turnbull and Cutcliffe who
would then put it on.

Superintendent Morgan has submitted two accounts in connection with the erection of No. 2 school-house on the Six Nations Reserve which I am not prepared to pass for payment as I consider the charges excessive.

In letter of 2nd instant, the accounts were referred to Superintendent Morgan pointing out the excessive charges and no satisfactory explanation has been given.

The first is the account of Turnbull & Sons for $711.74 for repairing two hot air furnaces. New furnaces could be bought for $300.00 each. The large item in the account is $247.60 for labour and yet we have only two old furnaces overhauled.

The other is the account of Turnbull & Cutcliffe for painting material amounting to $783.53 which seems excessive for painting a two room school-house. Six Dollars ($6.00) a gallon has been allowed for paint while last summer paint for other school-houses on the Reserve was purchased for $3.60 for outside white and at that time this same firm quoted $4.95 per gallon.

The reason given for the high price of the paint is that the roads were bad and paint could be got in small quantities only but the gross amount required could have been contracted for.

It is also stated that the paint is a superior quality to what was supplied for use on other school-houses and no reason given why better paint was required on this building than on others on the Reserve.

It is desired to know if you favour passing these accounts as the firms are asking for payment.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the memorandum hereunder regarding certain accounts in connection with the rebuilding of No. 2 school on the Six Nations Reserve, I beg to recommend that the accounts be paid as I consider them fair and reasonable for the work performed.

With regard to the furnaces the cost of which was $711.04 this price includes the complete overhauling of not only the furnaces but all the piping. In the memorandum hereunder it is noted that new furnaces could be bought for $500.00 each. This amount is only for the furnaces and represents a small portion of the necessary labour and material required to make the installation as it now stands, and it would therefore have cost considerably more than the amount of the accounts submitted, if new furnaces had been installed.

With reference to the account of $763.62 for paint, this includes in addition to paint all items such as ventilating registers, roofing, and hardware, and I consider the price charged is reasonable. This building is a flat roof construction and the charge of $449.50, which is included in the amount above mentioned, is for the laying of a felt and gravel roof. I may say with reference to this work that the great portion of it was carried out in the fall and although I made several efforts to visit the site of the building I was unable to do so on account of the roads. I have, however, every confidence in Mr. William Russell, the Indian who acted as foreman, as in my experience his services have always been entirely satisfactory.

Dear Sir:

"Veneering No. 2 school with brick."

At the last Council meeting it was decided to call for tenders to veneer No. 2 school, which was rebuilt two years ago, with brick.

I have this morning had a talk with Mr. Harper, who points out that when this is being done certain exterior alterations should be made with which I agree.

In Mr. Standing's report this year he recommended that the long room at the back of the school should be adapted for the use of a Continuation school, which I think the Council will favourably consider; alterations therefore will be necessary to the entrance.

Mr. Harper suggests that the existing wooden stairs should be removed and that before starting to veneer that the two windows in the basement should be turned into doors and the necessary stairs put in instead.

Mr. Orr will remember that the basement of this building was never finished, the concrete floor being in a very bad condition and as there is quite a lot of water lying there, which is rusting...
the new furnace which recently cost over $700.00 it would be advisable to have this also attended to. The water finds its way down the stairs at the back of the basement which should also be remedied.

Mr. Harper tells me that there are one or two points with regard to the hospital about which he would like to see Mr. Orr. One of these, a serious one, is the old question of coils and heating apparatus furring up with lime. The coils in one of the furnaces has already completely burnt out and has to be replaced and it will not be long before the entire heating apparatus follow suit. The only solution appears to be a large soft water tank as there is no doubt that the softening apparatus should be filled with soft water and the water softener apparatus is useless.

I have also called for tenders for the flooring of the Police stable and have, in discussion, with the Corporal came to the conclusion that the suggestion of filling in and concreting the floor will be too costly.

I have not yet all prices but imagine that the cost will not exceed $150.00 to floor with oak.

If Mr. Orr could spare time to come down sometime soon it will be greatly appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

Lt. Col. O.E. Morgan,
Supt. Six Nations.

Sir,

Mr. John Clark head teacher of the Chawaken School on the Reserve where he has been employed for the past few years has given every satisfaction to the school board, Chiefs and members of the Six Nations. He is a married man and has experienced difficulty in procuring house accommodation for himself and wife. For the past year or two, he rented a house from Chief J. N. Johnson, who notified him that he required the house in June. Mr. Clark could not procure another dwelling and was therefore considering resigning as teacher there. The trustees of the Chawaken School requested him to defer his resignation until they could lay the matter before the Chiefs in Council, which they did at their meeting held on April 28th, when the Council decided to build a dwelling house in Chawaken for a residence for the teacher. The minutes of which Council meeting was duly forwarded to you. After the meeting I requested the trustees to prepare the plans and specifications for the teacher's residence and ask for tenders to be returned at the Council meeting to be held in May, when the Chiefs would consider the plan and tenders and if approved of, the matter could be fully reported without further delay to the Department. Chief Johnson one of the Trustees prepared a plan and specifications for a house which I enclose.

The house is of the same plan as the one Chief Johnson proposed to build for the teacher residence, but the Chiefs would not accept his offer. Mr John Clark the teacher informs me that he prefers the house of Mr John Hill to any of those offered for sale. All the houses offered are convenient to the school. I consider the offer of Mr John Hill's the best value and most desirable of all properties offered. in some cases. They are not 6 inches. It sometimes happens
in finishing up a roof that you have to spread out a little. I
believe on a large contract it is an important thing to have
them 4 inches to the weather. If I get work to do I am
contracting all the time. I do not get a great deal of work. A
great deal depends upon the pitch of the roof whether the shingles
should be laid 4 inches to the weather. If it was a flat roof
they might not have shingles at all. As I said before the
shingles might be 5 inches to the weather up near the ridge, so
you could work out your courses properly.

The joists on the verandah floor are laid lengthwise.
I suppose the verandah would be about 30 feet. By the prammer
there is some support under the joists; on the outside course
there is, laid on blocks. The blocks are situated under the
stick of timber that is laid in the front. The joists are
carried by your trimmer. They were 16 feet—joists. They are
on the trimmer. There is nothing underneath them on the centre
joists, courses. The old support is on the outside timber, which is
far better than putting it on cedar posts or anything else. It
was not required to put cedar posts in. "Joists for verandah
floor........5' cedar posts" We did not do that but placed a
trimmer instead of it.

I do not know how large a light was of glass was in that
door. The door we originally brought for the dining room was put
in the pantry. We were not going to put in very small panes
of glass. I do not know how much glass is in the present
dining rooms door; I do not know as it was mentioned in the
specifications. We put on new locks where it was required. We
put a new one in the front door. We gave them two keys, they
cost 75 cents. This house has been repaired several times; I
think this is about the third time since Mr. Clark's has
been in it. We put a new waste pipe in there. It did not
call for a trap. I do not think that is necessary, not in the
position that the sink is. A trap is to cut off the draughts
of air from the waste pipe. It might be quite a number of shapes,
I did not think it was necessary there. I do think it is
necessary some places. I do not have it in my own house. We ran
this pipe right into the overflow of the cistern. We had
nothing to do about whether the overflow was running right
or not. Instructions were to run it into the drain, and we did so.
It was supposed to be running properly. I did not pay any
attention to it. Mr. Clark complained about these doors, when he
found it was an oversight in leaving them out of the specifications.
He objected to the little bit of light in the dining room, and
Thomas brought it back and exchanged it for another.

Mr. John Clark to MR. HOLLINRAKE:
I did not consent in any way to that dining room door
being patched up, and the other put in the pantry, for I was not
at home at the time.
They never told me about it. I objected to Hill about it. I objected to the waste pipe going into the over-flow; it was not done under my instructions. I do not know that I mentioned the matter of trap to him. The night that Jamieson called at the house he did not wish to come inside the door, and I asked him in and persisted that he come in. He would not sit down; he said that he came in to look over the work. I had just come in from school and asked him if he had his specifications, and he said No, the contractors said they had done all. I said "Mr. Jamieson, are you inspector, or do you take the contractors word and he immediately turned in a heated manner, and went out; he never sat down.

To MR. HEYD: I was not hot myself. Any person would be agitated over it. I asked for a waste pipe, and waste pipe includes a trap if it is properly put in. I did not have a waste pipe before. I suppose it was the suggestion of the Inspector of works that the waste pipe should run into the over-flow. I objected at the time it was put there, to the Inspector; I objected before it was put in. He would not give me any answer at all.

Case Closed.

The Teacher's residence in the village of Ohsweken has been rented for sometime to Mr. Fredlander. He gave notice to the Council that he will vacate the premises at the end of this month. I would recommend this minute for your approval.

No. 12.

Moved by Wm. Smith seconded by Ambrose Hill

That in the application of Isaac Doxtator asking to be reimbursed for having invested and lost a sum of money with members of the old Council, that same be not allowed.

Carried.

This is an old claim of which the Department may have some recollection. Isaac Doxtator loaned the old Chiefs in 1921, $500.00 and in return received a Quit Claim on the house known as the Teachers residence in Ohsweken. Apparently the money was not paid into band funds, but used to finance a trip to England by the late Levi General, to press some claims to the Crown.

Doxtator occupied the residence referred to for four years or more without his rights being questioned. But on the elective system being instituted, the new Council passed a resolution dispossessing him of the residence which received the approval of the Department. It is impossible for me to rightly judge all the circumstances of something which happened so far back, but it has the appearance of an individual's right to some consideration and justice, being completely submerged in the intense struggle between the old and new times. However, the Department will appreciate the situation with their past knowledge better than I can, though in my opinion on compassionate grounds, Doxtator's small pension of $25.00 a year might have been increased a little, to compensate him slightly for the loss of all he possessed, in perhaps a mistaken cause.

E. P. Randle,
Supt. Six Nations.

Dear Mr. McGill,

My attention has been called to an appeal from Isaac Dovtate, an elderly Six Nation Indian in regard to a claim that I think should be taken up by your department and given some guidance in all fairness to British justice.

It seems Isaac Dovtate had advanced money to the old chief council in 1921, which was the recognized authority for administration at that time and in lieu of this money amounting to $625.00, he was promised a house and lot was conveyed to certain property a house and lot was conveyed to him Dovtate in which a quit claim deed was given by the then council.

Now owing to the difference of opinion that exists now among the Six Nations regarding the system of electing council or retaining the old system of chiefs they develop so rapidly especially when a case as old as this comes up.

As to how that money was spent whether wisely or otherwise, I do not think enters into the case. The system of administration at that time should be recognized and their oath given honored and I feel that if this council had recognized the claim and settled it would have helped to heal a breach and given recognition to the spirit of tolerance which in general...

Dear Mr. Wood,

I have your letter of the 14th September dealing with the matter of recouping Levi Doxtator of the Six Nations Reserve for money advanced by him some years ago, previous to the adoption of the Indian Advancement Act on the Reserve.

In the event of the Superintendent of the Six Nations reporting Doxtator to be in need of relief, any necessary assistance will be authorized and paid for out of appropriation.

OTTAWA, Canada.

Dear Sir:

We have been consulted on behalf of Isaac Doxtater, an Indian residing on the Reserve here at Brantford. It appears that in 1921 he purchased from the then hereditary Chiefs a portion of land and premises known as Teacher's Residence at Ohsweken and paid the sum of $625.00. He resided on the premises until the Spring of 1925. In the interval there had been a change in the method of Government on the Reserve and an elective council became the governing authority rather than the hereditary chiefs. In the Spring of 1925, six months after the new council took office, they dispossessed this old gentleman of the property. Since that time he has been endeavoring without a great deal of success to obtain some redress. The action for dispossession was taken by the then local Superintendent, Col. Morgan, and Doxtater finally left the place on the 1st day of May, 1925. He holds a proper quit claim deed from the Chiefs and he is now in very serious circumstances and except for a small old age pension, which he receives, is without any means of support. Personally, it appears that this man has suffered a great injustice and I feel that if this matter was brought to the proper authorities at Ottawa, his case would be fairly dealt with. If you wish me to forward the quit claim deed, I would be glad to do so. It was approved by the Council on the 1st day of August, 1921.

Yours truly,

Trepanier and Hagey.

Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

We wrote to you on April 6 last on behalf of one Isaac Doxtater. Since then we have not heard from you in the matter.

We feel that we cannot urge too strongly the unfair situation that this old gentleman finds himself in. He bought the property in good faith from the proper authorities in 1921, had possession and title to the same for over four years. The new Council then dispossessed him of the property. It is true, of course, that there was a strong feeling existing on the Reserve concerning the change in the method of the administration. As far as Doxtater was concerned, he was not involved in this, but he is now called upon to suffer in his old age by the very unfair attitude adopted by the present governing body.

Mr. George Wood, the representative of Brant in the Federal House, has been in to see the writer concerning the matter. It appears that he has investigated it also, and feels that a great injustice has been done. Personally, we feel that your Department should either cause the present Council to re-imburse Doxtater, or if this is not within your rights, that the Indian Department then should take some action.

We would appreciate hearing from you at your earliest opportunity with regard to this matter.

Yours truly,

Trepanier and Hagey

Dear Sir:

Re #32-2-8 Levi Doxtater

We thank you for your letter of May 5th.

Doxtater did not as you state advance any money. He paid over the money and in return therefor received a Quit Claim Deed from Levi General on behalf of the Six Nations Council. The matter was approved in Council on the 1st August, 1923, and is marked approved as of that date. It is possible that you have not seen this deed, and we enclose a copy herewith.

We realize that certain moneys were advanced by various members of the Tribe to the old Council for purposes which you state could not be countenanced by the Department. We feel, however, that this is not the situation here. This old man purchased a piece of property and received a proper deed in accordance with the custom of the Council. If you feel that it is necessary for the Member in Brantford, or the Member for Brant to take this matter up with the Minister please advise. Personally we feel that the matter should be followed up to the last resort.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I beg to report the minutes of the General Council held on the 3rd & 4th inst.

No- No. 11

On the recommendation of the School Board the Council decided to build a new school at No. 5; the present building is an old frame building totally unfit for school purposes, besides it is too small for the number of children attending it. The number of school children of school age in the vicinity is 85, the number on the register is 70 and the average attendance during the last quarter was 56.4%. To carry out the decision it will be necessary to have plans prepared for a building large enough to accommodate the children. It might be that the plan first prepared for the school at Elliott's corner be used. I beg to recommend that the decision be approved.

No. 13

The Council decided to permit Rev. A. B. Farnie state to the Council the message he got from the Visiting Supt. Mr. Smith.

Mr. Farnie then came forward and stated the message he received through the phone from the Visiting Supt. Smith regarding the two new School houses to be built this year. It is the desire of the Department that the contracts should be let in as little delay as possible so that the work may be started as soon as possible.

The Council after careful consideration decided as follows-

1. That the season for hauling heavy materials for these school houses is past and that No. 5 School Section have a School House which serves the purpose up to the present time and is good enough to serve the purpose which is required for some time yet and so it was decided to abandon the Idea of building a new School House for No. 3 at present.

2. The Council decided to build a new School House on Wm Captons corner because this is very urgent as there is no school house in this section of the Reserve and where the children living in Onondaga portion of the reserve could come over the river on ferry boat and attend with safety and the cost not to exceed $1200.00

I will report under separate cover.
Sgd Gordon J. Smith
